cards.title: Coaching leaders need to be empathetic to have a successful coaching dialogue. They need to understand the point of view and experiences of others.
Coaching leaders don't have to agree with every opinion, but they need to be curious and try to understand where others are coming from.
An essential part of the coaching mindset is to explore each situation through the eyes of the direct report.
Coaching leaders always keep the best interests of the other in mind.
Coaching leaders strive to consider the motivations, interests, and perceptions of others--not only as related to the work at hand, but also related to their career development.
To be a true coach, put yourself in the shoes of the other party.
Remember: It's about them, not about you.
It is important to hold positive regard for those you lead.
To develop, people need to share their weaknesses and struggles. They need to be vulnerable. People will not share their vulnerabilities if they don't feel safe.
In the workplace, people tend to see vulnerability as a weakness. Coaching leaders view it as a strength and encourage it.
Coaching leaders share their vulnerabilities to engage others. By modeling vulnerability, coaching leaders provide a safe environment for development and change.
Coaching discussions must come from an authentic place on the part of the coach to resonate with the other party.
Share with those you lead some of your current and past struggles.
Encourage others share their struggles or mistakes with you.
Be authentic in sharing feedback--even negative feedback. Express concern, not judgment.
Creating trust takes time.
Coaching leaders establish trust by taking others into account, listening, and respecting varied points of view.
Building trust is also about demonstrating expertise. People will approach coaching leaders to learn from their expertise, reputation, and experience.
Coaching leaders maintain confidentiality.
Coaching leaders show appreciation of other's input.
Be candid, straightforward, and transparent. Keep information that was revealed to you in confidence.
Don't flaunt your expertise when it is not necessary.
Share your expertise to help your team develop and move forward in a collaborative manner.
Coaching leaders believe that people's potential can be unlocked through facilitation.
Coaching leaders don't provide a roadmap, but allow those they coach to discover their own solutions.
Coaching leaders who encourage problem solving will develop self-coaching employees.
Coaching for potential doesn't happen at a one-time meeting, but it is an ongoing process.
Recognize the potential of those you work with.
Help people explore options and solutions. Don't try to put out every fire yourself.
Remember: When people come up with their own agendas, they are more likely to be motivated and empowered to take action.

decks.name: Process vs. getting the job done

cards.title: Supervisory leaders emphasize process, routinization, and specific job roles. Workplace discussions are grounded in observations about job performance and expectations.
Coaching leaders care about getting the job done. They initiate discussions that focus on the goals, aspirations, and situations of others.
Coaching leaders look at a person's unique challenges and strengths instead of focusing only on results.
Coaching leaders want to guide, protect, and help their reports not only in their current  job role, but also in their career.
Coaching leaders appreciate the importance of language. They use nonjudgemental language to achieve better results.
Goal achievement is important, but look beyond the end result. Explore the process of how your direct report is attempting to achieve their goals.
Having a coaching relationship does not mean that the coach cuts people slack. The job still needs to get done.
Use nonjudgemental coaching language when you supervise.
Supervisors manage through coordination and authority.
Supervisory leaders specify how the work should be done, what steps the direct report should take, and what protocols they should follow.
Coaching leaders work with their reports by facilitating self-learning and helping them frame problems or issues at hand.
Coaching leaders help others reflect on the issues and help them explore possible solutions and next steps.
As a coach, you don't want to provide a map, but you want to facilitate map drawing.
You can provide a course of action while encouraging individual decision-making.
Recognize that those you lead have the cognitive capacity to come up with good ideas that will work best for them.
Supervisory leaders focus on and prioritize the organization's needs.
Traditional supervisors define the skills and goals their direct reports need to achieve within a specific period.
Coaching leaders partner with their direct reports to discover their goals and help them discover the path they will travel to get there.
Coaching leaders explore the personal aspirations of their reports and build on their strengths to fit the organization's goals.
Work to align the goals of direct reports goals with the organizational needs.
As much as possible, protect your direct reports from organizational shifts and changes of direction.
Help your direct reports explore their career goals and how they can achieve them.
Supervisory leaders view hierarchy as a source of power.
No matter how intimate and friendly supervisory leaders are, they never lose sight of their place on the pyramid.
Coaching leaders temporarily suspend the power dynamics associated with hierarchical relationships.
Coaching leaders rely on a culture of mutual trust and collaboration.
Set aside traditional organizational structures of hierarchy and authority when developing the coaching relationship.
Build a culture of mutual trust to maintain a good coaching relationship.
When coaching, shift your focus to the person you are coaching and partner to help them overcome their struggles.
Traditional supervisors communicate through performance evaluations.
Performance-evaluation meetings reinforce an organization's hierarchical structure.
The content of these meetings is limited to the consideration of goal achievement. There is an expectation that the direct reports will learn how to improve on their own.
Coaching leaders choose a process of ongoing development and assessment.
Coaching leaders maintain a continuous dialogue with their direct reports to help them overcome obstacles and achieve goals.
Replace traditional performance evaluations with ongoing coaching discussions.
Maintain the coaching mindset and use coaching language even when addressing a supervisory issue.
Invite your reports to share their strengths and successes as well as their struggles and development opportunities.
Coaching leaders facilitate by helping those they lead identify objectives, understand barriers, and figure out how to overcome those barriers to achieve their goals.
Facilitation is about encouraging exploration for change and growth.
The most difficult part of coaching is facilitation--that is, stepping back and allowing people to discover their own solutions.
Coaching leaders don't propose solutions; they ask open-ended questions.
Coaching leaders don't rush the process. They give people time to develop answers to questions.
Practice facilitation and it will become more natural to you.
You can facilitate to not only discover challenges, but also to help others find their strengths.
Remember: When you facilitate the discovery process, you empower those you coach to come up with the plan that is good for them.
Coaching leaders may act as advisors.
While coaching leaders cannot make their direct reports act in a specific manner, they can influence how their direct reports handle challenges and discover options.
Coaching leaders have experience and expertise. It is part of their role as a coach to advise by sharing their thoughts.
Advising is not the same as being authoritative. Coaching leaders advise with empathy and keep the best interest of their direct reports in mind.
Don't jump into the role of advising prematurely.
Tonality is important when advising--that is, don't be demanding.
Once you give advice, follow up to understand how the person received it.
Coaching leaders cheer others when appropriate.
Coaching leaders encourage direct reports to take on challenges and to not feel discouraged by setbacks.
Coaching leaders reassure their direct reports to help them develop a sense that they can overcome obstacles and achieve goals.
Coaching leaders develop sensitivity to signs of discouragement and inertia.
Coaching leaders acknowledge and celebrate the success of their team and colleagues.
Be authentic, don't cheer for the sake of cheering.
When you can't find big things to celebrate, try to acknowledge small accomplishments in order to motivate people.
Use cheering to reinforce to others that their contributions are valuable.
Coaching leaders are in a position to share their hard-won knowledge and skills with those they lead.
Different people have different learning styles. Coaching leaders are aware that one learning style doesn't fit everyone.
Coaching leaders explore where others may have a gap in their knowledge and help them gain the necessary information.
Coaching leaders bring others to a point where they can see their own way forward.
It is easier to learn from a leader who creates safety and trust.
Teach, but don't preach. Be aware of different learning styles.
Teaching is not the same as directing.
Teaching is about sharing knowledge and skills and expanding horizons.
Coaching leaders politically sponsor their team, direct reports, and colleagues.
Coaching leaders communicate to those on their team that they are in their corner.
Coaching leaders invest in the challenges of others as if the challenges were their own.
Coaching leaders publicly identify with their team. They let others in the organization know who they stand behind.
Coaching leaders help their team network and proactively introduce them to key players.
Be ready to support others and open doors.
Be aware that everyone isn't comfortable at moving ahead at the same pace.
Small, symbolic acts of public support can be big morale boosters.
Listening with curiosity is crucial to generating trust.
Listening inattentively or with impatience is a surefire way to stop dialogue. Projecting curiosity moves coaching leaders closer to full engagement.
Coaching leaders convey genuine interest in what others are saying and are not impatient to have their say.
Coaching leaders are fully present and are not distracted by phone calls, emails, and texts. They are committed listeners.
Coaching leaders send nonverbal cues that communicate interest and curiosity. They lean toward the speaker, maintain eye contact, and observe facial expressions and body language.

Listen with your whole body, not simply with your ears. Keep eye contact, and lean in toward the person who is speaking. Try to relax. These gestures send the message that you are present and engaged.
Let those you coach do the majority of the talking. Don't push people to get to the point. Give them the opportunity to struggle with their ideas and find the right words to express themselves.

Although others should do most of the talking, your role as a coach is to keep them focused. When you can, bring them back from a digression. By doing that you are also demonstrating that you are listening.
Coaching leaders take in the information they hear by listening, reading gestures, and processing the ideas and emotions of the other party.
Sometimes leaders are too busy thinking about the next argument they are going to make that they don't take in what they hear.
Coaching leaders pace the conversation to help people slow down and reflect to keep the conversation focused and effective.
The act of taking in the intellectual and emotional content of the conversation demands that the coaching leader view the issue at hand from the perspective of the speaker.
Sideline other issues you are dealing with and focus on the conversation. Be fully present.
Project a sense of curiosity to truly understand where the other person is coming from; remember to absorb what is being said.
Notice what you are feeling but monitor your reactions.
Coaching leaders reflect back with accuracy by repeating key discussion points and key words they just heard.

There are two main reasons to reflect back. The first reason is for the coach to convey to the other party that are listening and have captured the key points. The second reason is to give the person who is being coached an opportunity to further clarify issues for themselves.
Summarize the main message. When people have conversations, sometimes information doesn't emerge in an orderly way, or they say so many things that the key issues get lost.
Coaching leaders help their direct reports focus on their important issues.
When people hear back what they said helps them to further and deepen their exploration of an issue.
Repeat meaningful words. When you repeat meaningful words, you let the other person know that you heard what is really important to them.
When a lot of information is shared, summarize the important issues you heard.
When you reflect back, you are asking the other party to confirm that you understood all the important points.
Choose one or two people with whom you'd like to practice the first three rules of the engagement process: 1. Listen with curiosity; 2. Take in what you hear; and 3. Reflect back with accuracy.
Open questions reinforce a coaching leader's interest in the other person and their belief in the value of their responses.
Questions can open up new avenues of discussion and understanding; poorly-phrased questions can stop meaningful dialogue.
When coaching leaders question, they help their direct reports explore, self-reflect, and gain clarity.
Coaching leaders avoid questions that can be answered with one-word answers. Short answers do not open the door for reflection.
Coaching leaders use questions to broaden the speaker's scope of reference and reinforce the idea that there may be more than one solution to a problem.
Ask open-ended questions:  Who, what, where, when, why, and how? Don't try to squeeze multiple issues into one question.
As an example, “How could you do this differently?”
Don't ask questions that cannot be answered, are too complex, or sound like an interrogation.

Giving feedback for development is an opportunity for the coaching leader to react genuinely to what was said by the person they are coaching to help the person do their job better and feel better doing their job.
Coaching leaders give feedback by sharing their observations and reactions in a supportive and nonjudgmental way.
Feedback for development is not performance evaluation.
Feedback for development is part of the coaching conversation. By giving feedback, coaches respond to the issues being processed.
Feedback must be specific with concrete examples.
When giving feedback, the intention of the coaching leader is to help the person do better and feel better.
Make feedback nonjudgmental. You are evaluating the work, not the person.
If you are genuine and caring, even the most difficult feedback will be a gift.

Choose one or two people with whom you'd like to practice the five rules of the engagement process. Once you ask a question or give feedback, continue to listen with curiosity, take in what you hear, and reflect back with accuracy.
In the workplace, as in life, people often don't spend enough time thinking about what they actually want to achieve.
Goals must be measurable, attainable, and have a realistic time frame for achievement.
Coaching leaders help those they work with make sure their goals are aligned not only with the goals of the organization but also with the goals of others in the organization.
People often have more than one goal, and the coaching leader can help them clarify and prioritize their goals.
Take time to help your direct reports explore and clarify their goals.
Help your direct reports prioritize and align their goals with those of others as well as with the organization's goals.
Coaching leaders encourage those they lead to ask themselves open-ended, reflective questions.
Such questions are designed to stimulate the development of self-awareness.
Coaching leaders understand that their direct reports might not answer these questions immediately, and recognize that they might need time to reflect.
Coaching leaders care less about responses and more about the process of encouraging open thinking and exploration.
As the coaching leader you might say:  "Ask yourself, 'Where do I see my career in ten years?'”
You can prompt, “Ask yourself, 'What would I like to see happen?'”
Visualization involves imagining a future in which the individual has overcome obstacles and achieved their goals.
Once goal attainment is imagined, one can get a sense of what it would feel like to have the goal accomplished.
The act of imagining the path to success may also open up possibilities the person has not considered before.
Visualization is widely practiced in sports. Sports coaches routinely instruct athletes to “see the touchdown” and to imagine the movements that will lead to success.
Coaching leaders ask individuals to imagine various future scenarios. Where do they want to be? What would it be like to be there? What would it take them to get there?
Ask your direct reports to visualize their achievement of career goals and accomplishments.
Ask what they think the project they're working on will look like once it's completed, or what their job will look like a year from now.
Remember: You are setting a course for self-reflection that the person may want to engage in further on their own.

Internal blocks are the negative beliefs people have about themselves or about what might happen to them. People identify with these beliefs and lead their lives as if their blocks are who they are. The reality is that they are not their negative beliefs.
People may have beliefs, attitudes, or feelings that can stand in the way of personal goal achievement.
Coaching leaders understand that internal blocks can negatively affect work performance.
Coaching leaders help those they lead learn to identify those attitudes that might be holding them back in the workplace.
Coaching leaders do not attempt to solve their direct reports' personal problems, but help them deal with internal blocks they face at work.
Your goal is to help your direct reports maximize their strengths and address their weaknesses to promote their performance.
No one likes to not perform well. If they are not performing at the level they should, some inner block is in their way. You can help them overcome that.
Remember: You are not a therapist. You don't want to delve into problems that are too personal. Coaching leaders are NOT therapists.
Internal blocks are reasons people do not act in spite of their wish to act. Common internal blocks are fear of failure or embarrassment or feelings of self-doubt.
Problems arise when people become apprehensive or unsure of themselves and stop themselves from trying things they are uncomfortable with.
Internal blocks may appear as a habit or routine or even an unwillingness to upset the status quo.

Prejudice and stereotypes can be internal blocks. People may not realize that preconceived judgments based on gender, ethnicity, or appearance may affect their interactions with and expectations of others.
Coaching leaders are not therapists; yet, they can still help their direct reports overcome internal blocks and reach their potential.
Internal blocks are normal. Everyone has them in different degrees and about different issues.
You must be empathetic and patient when dealing with inner blocks. You are helping those you work with through a process of self-discovery.
Remember: Fear of failure can keep people from realizing their full potential. As a coach you can help people overcome fears and reach their potential.
There are two types of external blocks: The first set of blocks comes from the organizational context itself and the second comes from conflicting goals.
External blocks of the first type may come from inefficient work processes, mismanaged authority and influence, thin material resources, or poor allocation of human resources.
External blocks of the second type may arise when the goals of your direct reports conflict with goals of the organization or someone within the organization.
External blocks seem out of a person's direct control.
The role of a coaching leader is to help their direct reports to identify external blocks and explore ways to overcome them.

People tend to feel powerless to overcome external blocks. They feel it is not in their power to fix the situation. As a coach it is your job to help them find ways to overcome the obstacle and not get stuck in powerlessness.

Remember: People may not be aware of the agendas of other colleagues or the organization's agenda. As a coach you need to help them align their goals so that possible external obstacles will be addressed.
External blocks are real, but they can be dealt with.
There are four main external blocks:
1. Work Processes: Individuals blame inefficient work routines on their failure to get things done.
2. Authority & Influence: Individuals blame their lack of power or clout to move their agenda along.
3. Material Resources: Individuals argue they lack of resources to propel their plans or ideas.
4. Human Resources: Individuals feel that they don't have organizational support or the staffing to implement their ideas.
By asking the right questions, you can open up your direct report to approach a problem in a different manner or execute a project from a different perspective.
Give your direct reports a sense of what they can control.
Often there is an internal block behind an external one.
First, coaching leaders explore with their direct reports to identify the block.
Next, they help them explore ways to overcome the blocks that stand in their way.
Coaching leaders use the skills of questioning and visualization to help others identify blocks.
Internal blocks may be disguised as external blocks. When someone feels powerless to fix the external situation, they may be experiencing an internal block.
Self-reflective questioning helps people probe the internal logic of an obstacle that prevents them from moving forward. Visualization helps them see how they can move forward.
Remember: Your role is to listen and help explore. This means suspending judgment, doing some cheering, and clearing your mind of personal biases.
It is your job as a coaching leader believe that the person can overcome the block. Remind them of the times when they have demonstrated that they overcame blocks in the past.
The intent of the developmental conversation is to develop the person's performance.
It is important to stress the developmental nature of the conversation. That is, to downplay any language that is judgmental in nature.
People are usually quite aware of how they are performing. If the tone of the conversation is positive and safety is established, people will evaluate their own performance honestly.
Ask your direct report how they think they are doing. What is going well? What is difficult or challenging?
During the conversation, stress that you are a partner in the process. Ask how you can help getting the needed results.
If the person is not aware or responsive, share your observations emphasizing that your intent is for them to have the opportunity to improve.
By using coaching skills, leaders explore how their direct reports see the situation.
Exploration gives coaching leaders the understanding of how their direct reports see their situation.
Exploring the situation helps coaching leaders facilitate a process of framing the situation, discovering blocks, and exploring ways to overcome them.
Celebrate their successes, be open to hearing about their challenges, and learn about areas that they would like to develop.
Use the skills of listening and reflecting back to help explore where things are.
Demonstrate your intent to help them achieve and perform better. You want to steer away from judging their performance and indirectly shaming them or putting them on the defensive.

To understand how direct reports are progressing with goal achievement, coaching leaders must explore regularly with them with them. Are they achieving the short-term goals that will get them to their long-term goal?

As the coaching leader and their report have a better understanding of where they stand, they can develop a better understanding of where things should be going. They can explore feasible improvements and realistic targets.
When coaching leaders have continuous performance review conversations, they create the opportunity to help identify the obstacles that stand in the way of goal achievement earlier rather than later.

Feedback is the time in the performance review conversation where coaching leaders share their observations, suggestions, ideas, goals, and reactions to what they have learned. Coaching leaders keep the intent of development in mind.
Coaching leaders must not focus on an individual's characteristics, but rather on their behavior. Are they acting appropriately? How are they performing? How do they conduct themselves?
Positive feedback is important. Leaders must celebrate and acknowledge achievements in addition to pointing out opportunities to improve.
Effective feedback comes from a point of view of "What can we improve?" instead of "Where are we failing?"
Give constructive feedback that is direct, specific, and realistic. Avoid generalizations and focus on concrete examples.

Give your views and suggestions respectfully, without putting them down or being dismissive. There's a difference between saying, “What I have observed is...”  versus “I think my suggestion is clear and the way to go.”
Remember: Bring a positive mindset of "How can we do this better? How can we improve?" versus "This is bad, we need to fix this."
Actions are the specific steps needed to achieve the stated development goals.

Once the performance issues are clarified and obstacles identified, coaching leaders explore with their direct reports the specific actions they need to take to overcome the identified obstacles and move toward goal achievement.
Creating a detailed action plan might take may involve more discussion and planning than what can be accomplished in one performance review meeting.
Coaching leaders want their direct reports come out of the performance review conversation with an action plan that has specific next steps for development.
Once there is a mutual agreement about where the direct report would like to move, help them come up with the specific actions that will help them move in that direction.
Remember: Action plans should be realistic, with practical time lines, and with a clear understanding of what they will achieve.
The more actions are proposed by the direct report the more committed they will be to doing them.
Coaching opportunities are everywhere. The trick is not to miss them.
Any time someone asks you a question it can be a coaching opportunity.
Any time someone does something that you are annoyed about or that you disagree with is a coaching opportunity.
Make a point to find coaching opportunities throughout the day.
Coaching leaders understand the need to avoid setting agendas or telling people what to do or how to do things.
Coaching leaders should avoid falling into the trap of giving direction disguised as a question.
Example: "Did you think about speaking to the IT department?" Basically the message is: "I think you should speak with the IT department."
A coaching question: "What might you do about this situation?"
Explanation: Asking a question encourages problem-solving.
Resist the urge to tell people how to do things.
When people hear someone's problem, sometimes their tendency is to connect it to a similar situation they they experienced, and talk about that.

An example: "I just had a very difficult exchange with Dan." If the response is, "Yes, I know, I spoke with him last week, he is so arrogant. I can't stand it" then the discussion turns from the other party to the leader.
A coaching response: "I understand your frustration. How are you doing with that? Is there anything you would like to do to follow up on this?"

Explanation: In the first case the leader shifts the focus to herself; in the second, she keeps the focus on the person who came to her, listens and explores if the other party needs to say more about the incident.
Remember: Connect with the other party on their terms, and not on your terms.
Getting true feedback from reports is crucial to a leader's development. When leaders receive difficult feedback they often dismiss it or become defensive.
Example: "You came out very harsh in the team meeting today"; response: "I don't think I was that harsh. You guys really screwed up."
A coaching response: "Can you say more? How did I come off? What was the impact on you and the team?"
Explanation: The first response neither shows the coaching leader's awareness nor creates safety for giving difficult feedback.
When leaders are faced with problems, their initial reaction is a desire to solve them.

Example: A leader is told by her CEO that one of her businesses is not performing well. She responds by going to the head of that business with a list of things she wants him to do to improve the business performance.
A coaching response: The leader goes to the head of that business, shares the CEO's message and explores with him what he can do to improve the business performance.

Explanation: By exploring with the business head, the leader communicates that she has trust in him to lead the business, acknowledges his ideas about improving business performance, and encourages motivation over defensiveness, embarrassment, and resentment. It also allows for more ideas to be explored.

decks.name: A good idea is only a start

cards.title: It's often said that leaders achieve success because of their great ideas or irresistible vision.
If that's the case, are history's greatest leaders truly original thinkers? Was Jeff Bezos the only person to conceive of an online store?  Of course not.
Good ideas and vision help leaders keep focus, but their initial idea wasn't the sole cause of their success.
You can succeed if you develop the pragmatic, political skills to get people to rally around your idea and work to make it a reality.
Ideas are just the first step.
More often than not, ideas require more than one person to turn them into realities.
There is no "lone ranger" in startups or established organizations who can do it alone.
You can succeed if you develop the pragmatic, political skills to get people to rally around your idea and work to make it a reality.
It is harder to get things done alone.
Ultimately, leadership is about execution. To execute, there are a series of steps change leaders need to take.
There is no big mystery about execution. The skills of execution are attainable and achievable.
Change leaders are evaluated by whether they are able to take their vision or ideas and turn them into concrete realities.
Change leaders aren't evaluated on their creative ideas, but by their ability to achieve results.

It isn't the vision of a new policy, program, or product that matters, but the executed policy, program, or product. The premise of pragmatic leadership is that accomplishments count more than aspirations.
Never rest on the laurels of your ideas; always expand alliances.
Your success depends largely on your ability to get things moving.
A coalition is a collection of individuals committed to achieving a common outcome.
Organizations are structured systems in which things get done by people working together.
A coalition mindset is a way to deal with people's fear of free-riders and zero-sum games.
Action is created through the mobilization of power; power is mobilized through the mobilization of people.
Successful leaders create a coalition mindset.
When you establish a coalition, you send the message to potential allies that they are important, they are powerful, and you need their support.
Creating a coalition is distinctly different than “giving” through empowerment.
Coalitions are necessary when there are far-reaching consequences, high perceived risk and complexity, and an impact on resource allocation.
Change can still encounter opposition and resistance even after it is put in place.
In the later stages, resistance can take the form of sabotage--detractors can make overt and covert attempts to derail change processes.
Change leaders ensure that people are in their corner so they can oversee and monitor both positive and negative feedback.
By strengthening and expanding their coalition of support, change leaders not only curb the risk of personal attacks, but also reduce the risk that resistors will take action against them.
Start by targeting certain groups who are strategically crucial to the success of your agenda, then move outward.
Always anticipate sabotage. Never let it blindside you and set you back.
The more people who are in your corner, the more people who will advocate for you and your idea. You need to advocate for them as well.
Should the initiative ultimately fail, a coalition prevents the responsibility from falling on the shoulders of a single person.
The coalition serves the dual purpose of increasing the potential of change agenda's success while diffusing the risk of failure across a broader spectrum.
Coalitions are vehicles for risk taking.
Accept failure and risk as part of the innovation process.
Don't take unnecessary risks and ruin your personal credibility.
As an innovation becomes institutionalized, there may still be pockets of resistance.
The best defense in these situations is a strong coalition of supporters who together can counter critics' claims.
Assuming coalition members are satisfied with the outcome of a current effort, they will be a change leader's likeliest source of future support.
Any unintended problems that may crop up might call a change leader's ability and competence into question. There will be those who won't hesitate to call a change leader's efforts a failure.
Much like minimizing the risk of sabotage efforts, building strong coalitions will make it risky for resistors to seek revenge.

Always keep in mind that unintended problems that may crop up might call your ability and competence into question. Even if you are successful, there will be those who won't hesitate to call you a failure.
Remember: It is never too early to begin to build support for your next initiative.
To justify ideas to a large audience change leaders need a coalition--that is, a  platform of support.

The more people who become closely tied to and actively support an agenda, the more likely it will be perceived throughout the organization as a good idea, and the greater its chances are for success.
Coalition members can and will advocate for the ideas of a change leader to a wider audience.
Don't build a large coalition simply for personal legitimacy. You first have to focus on building a successful agenda.
Ensure coalition members are equipped with the right tools and information to discuss your change effort.
People and organizations will always have reasons to not act. There are always reasons to avoid change.
Resistance to change initiatives begins early and can continue throughout the change cycle.
It is generally easier to attack an idea than to propose an alternative.

If the opposition is well organized, they may be able to produce a viable alternative to a given change effort, with the intention of disrupting or terminating the progress of a change leader's initiative.
Resistance is a rational response for those who have something to lose.
Don't get frustrated with hesitation or inaction. Resistance and concern is normal.
Resistance may be productive. It points to the threats that change may bring to a functioning system.
Even weak resistance can slow processes of change.
People have embedded knowledge, that is, routines, processes, and habits. Change has the potential to encroach on their comfort zone.
Change is hard and it might not work. People fear failure and the consequences of failure.
If new initiatives shift responsibility, people might fear a loss of status.
New agendas might be unfamiliar to people, making them skeptical if not negative.
Anticipate responses to common questions like, “Why should I give up something that works for me?” and “What will I get?”
Present your change agenda clearly; always be open to questions and concerns.
New agendas can not only threaten corporate values that have so far succeeded but also challenge the status quo.
It is no secret that organizations have rigid structures. New ideas might require overlapping functions or combining departments that might take a lot of time and resources to change.
Organizations might resist change because they already made an investment in one direction. They don't want to lose sunk costs.
Organizations are often bound by contractual agreements or have an arrangement with a client base that they cannot break or dare not abandon.
Present change initiatives in analytical terms with concrete numbers and solid projections.
When possible, stagger change and be incremental. Don't overwhelm them.
Some organizational actors, especially those with long experience and a knowledge of organizational history, might employ this rejoinder to a new proposal.
The proposed idea may remind critics of previous organizational efforts that may have been lauded at the time but never got off the ground.
Some stakeholders may point out that similar ideas failed in the industry or sector.
Embed yourself in the organizational history to make sure your idea stands apart from previous efforts. Be ready to explain these differences concisely.
Think of why previous change efforts failed and present ways to address those obstacles.
Learn from case studies of the implementation of similar ideas or strategies in your industry.
Resistors may try to throw change leaders off-course by suggesting that their ideas will put the organization in danger.
Critics may prefer to play it safe with the status quo rather than take a chance or make a gamble with the unknown.
For them, the uncertainty surrounding a new idea is so overwhelming and frightening that embarking on a new idea is not worth the risk.
Critics might suggest that an idea has not been thought through.
Some critics are able to magnify any seeds of doubt.
Consider and explain the far-reaching implications of your idea.
Think of the fears key organizational actors may have. What is at stake for them?
Create ways to limit risk and alleviate fear.

decks.name: That idea will actually make things worse

cards.title: A common objection used to stop a new idea before it has a chance of survival is to argue that any shift from the status quo will cause harm.
Resistors may say something like, “This idea is just going to backfire. It will make things worse instead of improving them.”
In this instance, resistors are certain that a new idea will lead to disaster.
Resistors counter new proposals with a sense of their own assurance, their own knowledge, and their own certainty.
These critics will try to enlighten those they oppose to perspectives, angles, and horizons that they feel weren't anticipated.
Know that every new idea has consequences--some good and some bad.
Reinforce the positive features of your new idea.
Think of ways to reduce the potential fallout from less-than-optimal consequences.

decks.name: Your proposal won't change a thing

cards.title: A favorite tactic of critics is to suggest that new idea is illusory or cosmetic, and that it won't help the organization in any significant way.
No matter how senior a change leader is, resistors will try to make them feel young and naïve.
These critics may try to instill a sense of futility. They will say that it's all been tried before and that there is no reason to act in haste.
They will say that it is inevitable that nothing can be changed, so don't even try.
Make a comprehensive list of what your proposal will change, how it will change, and when it will change.
Illustrate why inaction may have negative, long-term consequences.
Address the specific reasons critics think your idea will not change anything.

decks.name: You don't know the issues well enough

cards.title: This common argument may be disguised and delivered in multiple ways.
Resistors may say that a change leader does not have the depth of knowledge to take on a particular issue.
Critics may attack a change leader's credibility, experience, and knowledge.
Resistors might try to take advantage of any perceived lack of technical knowledge or limited experience on the change leader's part.
Establish your credibility by building coalitions and justifying your initiatives.
Find an ally who has the relevant experience and knowledge that you do not have.
Show your research, results, and efforts. Point to the numbers and facts.
An objective may be above reproach, but to its critics, the proposed implementation processes might be flawed.
Critics can put the initiative in jeopardy by questioning a change leader's ability to implement a proposal.
Resistors often don't directly attack or oppose an idea; instead, they try to derail the effort by questioning a how the change leader proposes to execute.
This argument is most effective when the leader has a notable weakness or vulnerability.
Be open to prudent suggestions, but don't lose sight of your goal.
Show others a track record of success or a detailed plan of action.
Anyone can suggest that a change leader's motives for suggesting an idea might not be pure. Critics may imply that a change leader is really after something else when proposing a new agenda.
Distrust in some organizations is rampant. No one is immune from criticism.
It is relatively easy for a detractor to find some level of inconsistent or conflicting motives.
If change leaders aren't careful, every action they take will be analyzed by critics to expose them as a Machiavellian!
Be prepared to answer charges of personal motivation and intention.
Be as transparent as possible. The attack of having “ulterior motives” can be persistent.
Always share gains, glory, and success with your team.
Top Dogs are the organizational decision makers. They have official authority and veto power.
All organizational activity happens on their watch. To paraphrase Harry Truman, the buck stops with them.
Top Dogs have the authority to approve decisions and to torpedo them.
The Top Dog need not necessarily be the CEO, but is the official authority from whom you need buy-in to move your idea to the next stage.
You might not want to present your idea to the Top Dog first.
There can be more than one “top dog" in an organization.
Gurus are organizational actors who are not involved in the daily life of the organization.
They can be senior individuals with a unique perspective, such as external consultants, the board of directors, or others who have influence on decision makers.
External consultants can be a sounding board for senior management when discussing new ideas.
Gurus, though on the periphery, have influence because of their unique position in the organization.
Gurus may be difficult to identify and even more difficult to map accurately.
Dealing with Gurus is a delicate matter. Spend too much time with them, and you may be coded as a sycophant or intriguer.

Spend too little time with them, and they may feel ignored or disrespected and in response, they may try to subtly delegitimize your efforts. Because the organizational role of Gurus is ambiguous, they sometimes can have sensitive egos.
Gatekeepers have authority over a limited set of issues, and they liaison between the Top Dog(s) and the rest of the organization.
Though formally under the supervision of the Top Dog, Gatekeepers are often left alone to make decisions that fall within their purview.
The Gatekeeper may be an individual, but typically gatekeepers are found in a group, like senior management or the finance committee.
They are the first-line decision makers in their area. Think of the director of marketing or the regional head of a manufacturing unit.
Gatekeepers are regarded as having substantial legitimacy. An investment of time with Gatekeepers is well worth the effort.
Gatekeepers have the positional authority to offer concrete support in implementing and executing your plan, and are well placed to put in a good word on your behalf with the Top Dog.
Players are influential stakeholders whose specific activities will be directly impacted by the change leader's initiative.
While Players do not have broad formal authority, their influence comes from their deep understanding of the specific activities and technologies necessary get the job done.
Players make things happen.
Players include the change leader's direct reports and subordinates
They are perhaps your most challenging constituency. Players will be your most vocal detractors and also your strongest supporters.
Make sure to give them the attention they deserve. They will be integral to your success as you move forward.
Players won't follow just because you might have a measure of authority.

decks.name: What is the scope of their goals?

cards.title: Do people have tinkering goals? That is, are their goals incremental improvements in the status quo of the organization?
Tinkerers are concerned about changes in specific rules and operations and tend to be risk averse.
Or do they have overhauling goals? That is, are their goals broader, with sweeping objectives?
Overhaulers are intent on putting the unit on a new trajectory. They look for fundamental transformation and dramatic retooling.
Tinkerers say to overhaulers, “You're moving too fast!”
Overhaulers say to tinkerers, “You're moving too slow!”
Make sure to evaluate the scope of your goals in relation to the goals of others in the organization.
Planners get things done by consolidating and focusing on systems of accountability.

Planners believe that problems can be anticipated and prepared for. They think they can identify all of the issues, problems, and variables in order to estimate, with some accuracy, likely outcomes and consequences of their decisions.
Improvisers get things done by being adaptable to new situations. They act then reassess.

Improvisers believe that because no one can accurately predict the future, it is necessary to proceed by trial and error. Act first and see what works. In other words, learn from experience and from what others are doing.
Planners say to improvisers, “You're out of control!”
Improvisers say to planners, “What happens if things don't go as planned?”
You need to decide when it is appropriate to plan and when it is appropriate to improvise.
By assessing the goals and approaches of others, change leaders can better anticipate who will accept or reject their change agenda.
Change leaders analyze and understand the agendas of others in order to anticipate how others will react to their efforts.
Change leaders understand that people have varying agenda styles. Some people may push the envelope when it comes to research and they may be conservative when it comes to financial planning.
A change leader's task is to expand alliances with as many stakeholders as they can.
Avoid staying only with your base.
If you throw a Hail Mary pass in an effort to reach out to those opposed to your agenda, you may fail.
Target people who have varied agenda backgrounds to join your coalition.

Traditionalists have tinkering goals and a planning approach. They believe change should be regenerative. For them, the purpose of change is to integrate the past successes of the organization into its current reality.

Traditionalists believe that the organization's current problems are due to a breakdown of tradition. They prefer change initiatives that focus on getting back on track, and, in some sense, returning to the old ways.
The strengths of the traditionalist are their cautiousness and their ability to reflect and draw on their experience.
The weakness of the traditionalist is that they might focus too much on the past, and ignore important differences between the past and the present situation.
Traditionalists prefer to build time into the process, believing that the longer the process, the more narrow the scope of change effort and the greater their control.
It is good to have traditionalists in your corner so you don't overlook the historical context of your change effort.
Be aware that traditionalists may try to block rapid change.
Too many traditionalist allies may make your effort seem conservative and slow moving.
Adjusters have tinkering goals and an improvising approach. They assume change is natural, inevitable, and unpredictable. Adjusters react to change only when necessary.
Adjusters are very much in the present, and are responsive to external circumstances. Adjusters constantly reassimilate themselves into the changing environment.
Adjusters are more comfortable making tinkering changes--improvising as they go along--crossing that bridge when they get to it.
Adjusters monitor the environment and try to isolate those factors that demand action. They act only when there is an absolute necessity for movement.
If you want to win over an adjuster, articulate the conservative nature of your goals.
If your goals are far-reaching, you may have to think about how to express them in terms of continuity rather than drastic change.
At the same time, show the adjuster that you are prepared to be flexible in terms of execution.
Developers have overhauling goals and a planning approach. They are committed to staying on top of things empirically, rationally, and incrementally.
They formalize, codify, and quantify the change process. The rhetoric of the developer agenda is one of operational proficiency.
They believe that a scientific or systematic method is essential for predicting and controlling impending change.
If the end goal can be defined, the steps needed to get there can be broken down into specific elements and reconstituted into a policy and a plan for organizational change.
Developers often have ambitious overhauling goals, but will pursue them in a methodical manner.
Give developers as much information and data as possible, including a delineation of each step of the process.
Developers may over-plan and box themselves in--don't get trapped with them.
If you want to win over a developer, you will need to show that you've taken the possible consequences of your proposal into consideration and have prepared for setbacks and pitfalls.

Revolutionaries have overhauling goals and an improvising approach. Their goal is to impose a completely new set of ideas that will fundamentally transform the mission and the processes of the organization.
Revolutionaries are likely to focus on new technologies, emerging markets, and up-to-the-minute research as the impetus for change.

While the revolutionary agenda often entails risk, revolutionaries believe that being nimble and reactive enables them to shift direction or reevaluate their situation more easily than those who invest in structured plans.
Show revolutionaries how your plan can lead to more changes and progress in the future.
Allow revolutionaries space to innovate and build on your plans and ideas.
Beware: Revolutionaries are always in danger of running off a cliff.
Once an announcement is made, there is no backing down. Change leaders can't retract an idea or write it off as a joke.
Change leaders don't bring ideas to the table until they are cooked, especially if they are not sure if their idea is something they want to pursue.
Change leaders will solicit advice or evaluations from a few people they trust.
Don't wait too long before announcing an idea, or you may miss a crucial window of opportunity.
You'll lose credibility if you propose an idea and never follow through.
Don't be a perfectionist. A demand for perfection could delay your launch. Someone else might be working on the same idea.
Agendas can fail if change leaders do not create a common language of understanding around their ideas and goals.
If leaders are not getting their message across, they might not be talking on the same level as the person whose support they are seeking.
Some may be critical of a change leader's ideas because they are too broad and focused on big strategic goals.
Others may consider a new proposal as too specific and excessively focused on micro steps.
Change leaders need to find the right balance and a common language that unifies broad goals with practical steps.
Even though parties may have a degree of common intention, how you frame the conversation will have an impact on your ability to move your agenda.
Persuade others to join the coalition by dealing with broad strategic issues first and then work out the nuts-and-bolts details.
Balance broad vision with concrete targets.
Change leaders know it's crucial to target a specific audience.
Change leaders know that if they talk to a select group of elite leaders first, it might look to others that they are engaging in a conspiracy.
Change leaders also know going straight to a broad audience may dilute their idea in an effort to appeal to everyone.
Target both leaders and the broad audience when pitching your idea.
The rational and logical appeal of numbers relies on careful analysis, detailed cost-benefit projections, and a well-structured presentation of alternatives.
Change leaders look at the numbers as they relate to money, time, and resources.
A rational scenario emphasizes the payoff to the organization, whether it takes the form of additional profits, a lower cost structure, or superior market position.
This is the primary type of argument used to justify action in all sectors of the economy.
There is usually not enough information, resources, or time to gather every last bit of data or conduct all of the analysis necessary to solidify an argument.
There's sometimes a difference between the magnitude of the numbers and how the numbers relate to certain strategies.
Some may pick apart your calculations or missed hidden costs or use “better” numbers.
The mimicry argument derives its legitimacy from the fact that other organizations have successfully implemented a similar initiative.
Think of “best practices.” The mimicry argument is often used when an organization lacks the time, resources, or data to pursue an alternative solution.
Leaders often use the mimicry argument as a heuristic to illustrate the benefits of a potential initiative.
Beware of organizational fads and fashions.
Others may thwart a mimicking scenario by examining the mimicked company's stock performance.
Sometimes change leaders can maintain that there was no choice and action is necessary.
Leaders can point to changing market trends, regulatory pressure, or consumer demand to move an agenda.
Smart leaders look for outside forces to create a tipping point for their ideas.
By pointing to outside pressures, leaders can avoid any blame.
Regulation provides an explicit measure to justify change.
Regulatory pressures and market changes are industry specific. Keep abreast of where the winds are going to blow.
Keep ahead of changing markets.
Embed your idea within a wider context.
This standards argument maintains that it is better in the long term to do the right thing, even if there could be a short-term dent in the bottom line.
A leader's customers, clients, and community may be very responsive to a decision to do the right thing.
It is hard for others to challenge an agenda if everyone agrees it is the moral course of action.
Standards or external expectations provide implicit reasons for change.
Use moral-emotional appeals only after making sure you have a broad enough base of support.
Moral-emotional appeals can ring false if done for the wrong reasons.

decks.name: I know what I'm talking about

cards.title: Leadership is not a game of modesty, although good leaders avoid outward arrogance.
Proactive leaders demonstrate to their colleagues that they have the knowledge to support their change agenda.
Inevitably, all leaders are going to have to communicate that they have the know-how to backup their ideas.
Leaders show expertise having a specialized type of knowledge, technical skill, or a distinctive package of experience.
Ultimately leaders show expertise by demonstrating their ability in a particular arena to define a problem and come up with a solution.
Ask yourself how you obtained the knowledge that makes you an expert. Reflect on the value of your expertise.
Communicate to others that your specialized knowledge makes your involvement essential to successful completion of your campaign.
Expertise in any area adds to your credibility as a change leader.

decks.name: The right place at the right time

cards.title: By being in the right place at the right time, leaders can find themselves with access to people, information, and knowledge that aren't available to others.
Proactive leaders can use this situation to lend credibility to their effort or to themselves.
Opportunity credibility can disappear as quickly as it came. Opportunity comes and goes, and as a result, opportunity credibility might be the least stable.
Yet, opportunity is very powerful force against the camps trying to de-legitimize your effort.
You might be able to create a sense of urgency based on opportunity, but  bring in others who have their own credibility based on position, integrity, or expertise.
You must be prepared to move quickly to translate your spontaneous insight into a concrete agenda.
Your challenge is to convince others and present the opportunity in a way that it doesn't threaten the position of others.
Leaders can establish credibility using their position and power within an organization.
While others may have insight and sway, some leaders can move an agenda simply because of their role in the organization.
Many assume that because leaders climbed the organizational ladder, they have the relevant expertise and the clout to make things happen.
Having positional authority may be a quick and efficient way to marshal a short-term coalition, but it is a questionable method of forming a long-lasting coalition.
Don't point to your uniform or your role in the organizational hierarchy too often.
Ideally, this type of credibility should be supplementary and understated.
Authority of this type must be subtle. Use it too often and your credibility will be reduced to autocracy.
Having integrity helps leaders push a sustained campaign that can overcome organizational hurdles.
Personal integrity is evaluated by the history of the leader's behavior in the organization.
A leader's reputation of integrity serves as reassurance to tepid coalition partners and can keep skeptics quiet.
Good leaders aren't totally altruistic, but will align their goals with those of the organization.
A leader's personal qualities can either stymie early resistance or increase it.
When forming a coalition, you should candidly consider the history of your own integrity.
If your integrity can be questioned, try to bring in others with unblemished histories to join you.
As other sources of credibility ebb and flow in a volatile organizational world, your integrity can be the buoy that keeps your coalition afloat.
Active supporters are involved in every detail of a leader's agenda--sometimes too involved.
Those who actively support a leader's initiative trust and believe in the leader's ideas. Supporters accept the leader's ability, position, integrity, and unique perception of a problem.
Active supporters likely believe that they (or their group, constituency, demographic, etc.) will benefit from the leader's plan, either directly or indirectly.
Active support is important in situations that require highly committed and motivated people.
Active supporters might try to micro-manage a leader's campaign or expect more than a leader can possibly deliver.
Active supporters never go home. There is a danger that they could become the extra chefs in the kitchen.
You have to remember that you're not recruiting cheerleaders, but you're asking others take an active role, even a small one, in your campaign.
If you oversell yourself and your idea, supporters might not be willing to compromise if circumstances change and you must scale back your goals or tactics.
Passive supporters are drawn to the leader's agenda because they can identify its benefits, but they have reservations about the leader's credibility
Passive supporters think the leader's idea may work, but they question the leader's capacity to go the distance.
Coalitions with a large roster of passive supporters are delicate. If perceived benefits dry up, passive supporters won't think twice about leaving a coalition.
Passive supporters may be just what you need. It means that they won't get in your way and hamper your efforts.
If you have enough active support from key stakeholders, gaining passive support is less important.
Think of passive supporters as free riders. They aren't in the business of making friends and backing grand visions. They stick around as long as they can expect to benefit from a plan.
Reluctant supporters say they are more than happy to help out or eager to lend a hand but they wind up not lifting a finger.
Reluctant supporters believe in the leader's credibility but don't want to go on the record saying “no” to the leader's agenda.
Reluctant supporters prefer to stay on the sidelines because they don't expect to benefit much from the leader's plan.
High credibility and low expected benefits are the ingredients for reluctant support.
In the short term, a coalition of reluctant supporters may look solid, but in the long term, it may contain more cracks than an old painting.
You risk repeated failure if you launch too many projects where the expected benefits are low.
If you have a lot of power in the organization, reluctant support may come in handy if you want to bolster the size of your coalition.
If all you need is to show that you have others behind your initiative, a cadre of reluctant support may be enough to get your idea off the ground.
When people believe that a leader has little credibility and expect few benefits from the proposal, they are likely to offer weak support.
Weak supporters want absolutely no responsibility for a leader's campaign and don't want to risk joining a leader. Frankly, they don't think the idea will succeed.
Weak supporters cannot be overwhelmed, but have to be brought along gradually.
You may never move weak supporters to a more positive type of support, but you want to keep their support stable so they don't become resistors.
Identify weak supporters as early as you can, and work to establish your credibility with them and to show them the expected benefits of joining your coalition.
Agenda movers must address people's primary fear of failure by reducing their anxiety.
In getting the buy-in, a leader is challenged to get others to overcome their fear of failure and to see success as a real possibility.
After all, leaders are asking others to invest time, effort, and perhaps resources into a project with an uncertain outcome.
Given that most people are risk-averse, the fear of failure is a source of anxiety and resistance.
You need to illustrate how your agenda relates to the goals and aspirations of others.
Ideas can be rejected because they sprawl or are too sweeping. Rein in the scope of your idea, and focus on exact costs and timelines.
Don't allow the drama and power of your idea to make you promise more than you can deliver.
Another potent fear is the fear of the new. Fear of the new has a different dimension than the fear of failure.
Habit is a powerful motivator, and there is comfort in doing things the same way. Change leaders have to sell the new.
Many won't challenge a new direction. But when change actually starts and routine, budgets, and work processes are discernibly different--people get conventional, fast.
The anxiety stems from the fact that employees are collectively used to doing things the old way are afraid of making future mistakes.
While people may say that they want new, innovative ideas, they may not be as receptive when dealing with the results.
You must be ready to reassure others, and expect that you'll have to do a certain amount of handholding.
Hollow reassurances of “It's going to be okay” will not get others to support your agenda. You have to let them know on a concrete level that you will be there for them.
People in organizations fear losing their identity, power, and position as change approaches.
Leaders need to take these concerns seriously and think of ways to preserve the status and resources of key stakeholders while implementing the new agenda.
The introduction of new ideas can create a shift in priorities and resources that will make some feel alienated, undervalued, or nervous.
Broad change initiatives make it difficult for people to protect old turf and old ways of doing things.
New ideas might imply an infringement on or an alteration of old status and power roles.
It's also important to reassure individuals that their support of your initiative will not necessarily come with the loss of power, prestige, or control.
Assuring others that you have their interests in mind will help you to get the buy-in.
Leaders have to show others what they will gain by joining their effort.
By showing that they have the smallest degree of self-interest does not mean that they have Machiavellian tendencies. It shows that they are rational human beings.
People won't join a coalition for the long haul, for the fun of it, or for, literally, nothing
Potential supporters seek benefits, social credit, and avoidance of blame.
There are two types of benefits: tangible (more resources) and intangible (more opportunities).
They are going to ask what's in it for them, their unit, and their team. You better be able to answer that question.
It takes a little creativity to come up with desirable intangible benefits, but in some cases, their worth is more than gold.
The greater the possibility of failure, the scarcer the resources, the more you have to focus on getting the buy-in.
To get the buy-in, agenda movers have to establish that while others are in their corner they are still capable of remaining independent.
Agenda movers have to show they have alternatives when approaching those they want on their side.
Agenda movers want to display independence without overplaying it.
It's crucial for leaders to give others a sense of their options while showing them that their support is needed.
The agenda mover can use one of four arguments to convey the message of semi-independence.
Don't be afraid of using power.
You want their support, but you also want them to know that "there are other fish in the sea."
Priority arguments are the agenda mover's effort to be a bit subtle about their priorities.
The agenda mover wants to avoid appearing desperate so the the other party won't sense weakness.
The agenda mover establishes the idea that they could reprioritize their agenda to keep the other party from overplaying their hand.
The risk leaders face is not appearing committed to their agenda.
Your challenge is to give the sense that you could reprioritize, but would rather not, if possible.
You don't want people to think you're desperate to drive just one set of ideas.
The self-enhancement argument makes the case that there are very few alternatives to moving the agenda ahead.
The agenda mover conveys to the other party that they have the capacity and skill to put their change initiative in place.
It needs to be communicated that the agenda is the only sure way to move ahead and there really aren't other viable options to choose from.
This argument works best with people who have expressed initial support. Agenda movers have to convince others that going along with the initiative is the best course of action.
Don't get ego involved. You want to suggest your idea is the best course of action in a subtle way.
The agenda mover can always say, “If you don't go with me, then I'll get someone else.”
Agenda movers can signal that they have other options and aren't afraid to use them.
Essentially, this is an explicit warning. If the leader does not get the support they are looking for, they can simply ask someone else to join them.
If the leader presents the case too strongly, the other party might stop caring or think their support won't make much of a difference.
You have to convey to your possible partners that you would like their support, but that you can find support elsewhere.
Only bluff if you can afford to lose the support.
The consequence argument subtly conveys to someone that if they don't buy-in there will be subtle, yet important implications.
The agenda mover can suggest that future reciprocity might be endangered.
Agenda movers use subtle language and do not overtly use threats.
Try not to damage personal relationships and never let your independence arguments be read by others as a threat.
You don't want to create a conflict-spiral that will consume your agenda.
Passive negotiators wait to take action.
Passive negotiators are not prepared to set the terms or determine the pace of the negotiation.
Passive negotiators are rarely prepared (and not willing) to move from their pre-set position.
Passive negotiators can be superficial and reactive.
Confidence gives passive negotiators the strength to hold their ground, but can lead to the ego trap.
Most people are passive negotiators. They take a position and defend it without reading the terrain.
Be proactive when it comes to negotiation situations.
Passive negotiators sometimes forget that negotiations are everyday occurrences.
Proactive negotiators anticipate and prepare.
Proactive negotiators are prepared to set terms and determine the pace the negotiation.
They are prepared (and willing) to change direction if the situation demands.
Proactive negotiators are reflective and responsive. Mindful negotiation implies awareness.
You must take control of the negotiation process and in a focused manner move it ahead.
Use proactive negotiating skills not only to resolve conflict, but also to avoid it.
Always be prepared and have empathy for the other party.

decks.name: The four characteristics proactive negotiators consider

cards.title: Proactive negotiators review the following four considerations before they get to the negotiation table.
1. Potential length of relationship: Proactive negotiators anticipate the length of the relationship.
2. Number of options and issues under consideration: Proactive negotiators map out the options that are available to each party.
3. Role of third parties: Proactive negotiators anticipate the importance of a third party in the negotiation proceedings.
4. Role of explicit power: Proactive negotiators know how much power will play a role in the negotiation.
Create a checklist around these considerations and write out your thoughts.
By being prepared, you'll be less likely to be surprised.
Thinking critically about your power and the issues at hand may help you realize that you don't need to or should not negotiate.
There are three classic negotiation situations:
1. Power negotiations: These tend to be win-lose. While problem-solving may be used, one party wants to win at the expense of the other.
2. Problem-solving negotiations: The goal is to work together. A bias toward win-win.
3. Power and problem-solving negotiations: Some issues are win-win, others are win-lose.
Proactive negotiators evaluate these situations based on the characteristics of the negotiation (i.e. length of relationship, number of uses, role of third parties, and role of power)
Some negotiators may hide behind a façade of cooperation, but they want to engage in power negotiations.
In a problem-solving negotiation, both parties want to help each other.
The power and problem-solving negotiation is what you most likely encounter on a daily basis in the workplace.
What makes the workplace both exciting and problematic is that it is a mixed negotiation setting.

In the workplace, some relationships are long term and others are short term. Sometimes there is room to think creatively about options and other times the pressure of deadlines limit reasonable alternatives.
Proactive negotiators must often renegotiate the rules, the processes, or the way things are happening in the organization to get results.
The sociologist Anselm Strauss coined the expression "organizations as negotiated orders." Everyday people negotiate.
Organizations operate on the basis of informal influence and so proactive negotiators have to pursue their agendas within the collective concern.
Expect to negotiate at all times. It is the same whether you work in a large organization or a startup.
Roles are not always clearly defined. There is always a give and take.
Negotiations give you the space to present the benefits and positives of your ideas.
Proactive negotiators are careful to think of all the issues involved in the negotiation situation.
Proactive negotiators look at the factors that are driving them to negotiate and consider the outcomes they are looking for.
Proactive negotiators are aware that issues range in size and scope and that different people care about different issues.
Much of the early jockeying at the bargaining table involves debate about the scope of issues.
Map out what issues are important to you and what issues are important to the other party. What do they want?
What are your goals? List them. What are essential goals? What are non-essential?

decks.name: Scope of negotiation: broad vs. specific

cards.title: While many negotiators think they know the issues, they likely do not have a handle on them.
Proactive negotiators know that what may seem to be an obvious, tangible, and explicit issue may in fact be only the tip of an intangible, implicit, and emotional one.
Proactive negotiators start by categorizing issues into two buckets: broad and specific
Broad issues are difficult to quantify and are not visible, like "standards" and "team excellence."
Specific issues are easy to quantify and visible, like "merit pay" or "20% by November."
Your specific, resolvable issues may affect the other party's broader issues.
Match your broad and specific issues with the broad and specific issues of the other party.
After proactive negotiators separate the issues, they will anticipate how the other party will see these issues.
Proactive negotiators need to discover if both parties are talking about specifics (nuts and bolts) or broad issues (principles).
Negotiating nuts and bolts revolves around sharing specific issues and working out the details (pay raises, holiday time).
Negotiating principles revolves around sharing broad issues and working out sweeping goals (vision, corporate strategy).
When you define the issue as specific and you anticipate that the other party will agree, be prepared for focused technical negotiations.
For broad issues, be prepared to understand what is hiding behind the stated principles.
Not talking at the same level means that one party is speaking about nuts and bolts while the other party is addressing broad issues or vice versa.
Not being on the same level impedes progress and stifles negotiations.

One party might talk about implementing a global diversity program while another might be talking about hiring a local team. While these parties may share the same goals, they'll talk past each other.
You need to be able to talk on both levels.

You can discuss excellence, innovation, and return-on-investment while hammering out an agreement for five percent pay increases, setting guidelines for improved customer service, or making a pledge to get new products to market faster.
What's crucial is that you and the other party are on the same page at the same time. When you're ready to move past principles and get down to specifics, it's helpful if the other party is, too.
Proactive negotiators list out each issue they want to discuss then decide which issue is important (a need) versus what issues are not as important (a want).
Needs are deal-breakers--that is, what one is not willing to concede.  If a negotiator is willing to give up something, then that something is not a need.
Wants are issues that are important, but about which a negotiator is willing to be flexible.
Distinguishing between needs and wants is often difficult and is highly subjective, but it forces the negotiator to prioritize issues.
The challenge for a proactive negotiator is to accept the subjectivity of this exercise, and frame the negotiation with a clear understanding of what the needs and wants are for the issue at hand.
The more needs you have, the tougher it will be to negotiate, especially if your needs and the other party's needs are not in agreement.
You can rarely succeed in bargaining if all your issues are of equal importance.
A want is the aspiration point that the negotiator would like to include the negotiation. A need is the resistance point.
Differentiating needs from wants is critical for developing tactical flexibility in negotiations, because bargaining always involves tradeoffs.
Know the difference between needs and wants. A salary hike might be a "need" while a new title might be a "want"
Proactive negotiators keep needs and wants within the scope of possible outcomes.
Proactive negotiators never flip-flop on needs and wants. Vacillating means a negotiator isn't ready to negotiate.
The biggest mistake negotiators make is not spending enough time differentiating one issue from another and distinguishing needs from wants.
Don't confuse needs and wants.

decks.name: Categorizing & prioritizing needs and wants of the other party

cards.title: After proactive negotiators create their own needs and wants list, they do the same for the other party by asking the following questions:
What is on their wish list? These items may be wants.
What are the things they might be willing to give up?
What are the things they need? What must they have no matter what?
What are the things they are not willing to give up?
You can do all the research in the world and still not be sure of your conclusions.
Nonetheless, as subjective as these questions are, to enter any negotiation without considering the perspective of the other party is a critical mistake.
Trying to gauge the other party's needs and wants helps you prepare for your presentation of your own needs and wants.
The needs and wants of all the parties to a negotiation determine the parameters within which the negotiation occurs and frame the "negotiation zone."
If the needs and wants of the involved parties change, the negotiation zone contracts or expands accordingly.
The negotiation zone is determined by a negotiator's capacity to present their needs and wants in the context of the needs and wants of the other party.
Proactive negotiators ask not only how they see their needs and wants, but also how the other party perceives their needs and wants.

You must begin to think of needs and wants in very quantitative terms. You must begin to understand that the zone of negotiation is bracketed by combination of your needs and wants and their needs and wants.
If you want to determine the playing field before you start the game, think about the negotiation zone as dynamic space with constrained parameters.
