How a negotiator views their alternatives and the alternatives of the other party determines their bargaining power and negotiation strategy.
Whether or not a negotiator agrees to a less-than-perfect outcome depends on their evaluation of their alternatives.
One of the biggest mistakes made in negotiations is miscalculating either one's own alternatives or the other party's alternatives, resulting in an over or underestimation of bargaining power.
Proactive negotiators evaluate their alternatives in terms of quality and availability.
Lastly, proactive negotiators want to know the probability of achieving each alternative.
When you have a lot of viable alternatives you can afford to leave your job or wait for the next seller.
Conversely, when you have fewer alternatives you can't risk slamming the door on any single opportunity.
Power plays a role in every negotiation and it is a factor that cannot be ignored or wished away.
Bargaining power is based on how dependent one party is on the other.  The more a party is dependent on the other party the less bargaining power they have.
Proactive negotiators determine their bargaining power by asking:
How dependent is the other party on me? Do they have alternatives to what I offer?
How dependent am I on the other party? How many alternatives do I have?
The quality and quantity of their alternatives determine how much power you have.
The quality and quantity of your alternatives determine how much bargaining power the other party has.
Your bargaining power is not simply based on your alternatives, but also on the other party's alternatives and the other party's view of your alternatives.
Often people don't come to the table because they think one party has too much power.
Proactive negotiators with or without power still want to get to the table.
Proactive negotiators establish interdependence and try to show that both parties can help each other.
While a boss may have more power over an employee, the boss can't dictate all terms of an agreement which leaves room for give and take.
When there is interdependence between you and another party, you know you can influence their outcome and they know they can influence your outcome.
Don't be afraid to enter into negotiations with someone with more power. Instead, present what you can offer and look for the other party's limitations.
Often both parties prefer not to make the first move, leading to an argument of who should go first.
An opening-round offer reveals information. It sets the dynamics of the negotiations in motion and they can't be rewound.
By prefacing an idea with "it's being considered" puts an issue on the table that needs to be discussed.
Proactive negotiators need to be prepared to make the first move--allowing them to direct and lead the negotiation process.
Each first move option contains risks, but also positives.
Remember: No matter how many "never minds" you say, once you say something, it cannot be erased. Be careful about proposing ideas that are rough or have not been thought through.
Don't be afraid of making the first move.
Proactive negotiators who make an offer right away often start with a concrete, specific, measurable proposal that defines what they expect and what they are willing to concede.
There is a tendency for negotiators to exaggerate the opening offer. It may be too low or too high.
The advantage of exaggerating the offer is that it makes it clear to the other party that a lot will need to be accomplished before an agreement can be reached.
The disadvantage is that an exaggerated opening bid may be seen as a classic non-starter, and the other party will decide that undergoing negotiations is useless and pull out.
Proactive negotiators only make the first offer if the other party can't refuse it and they are sure it will pay off.
You might make an opening offer that's so good that they can't refuse it--allowing you to gain leverage on other issues.
The advantage is immediate closure. The disadvantage is that it could be interpreted as weakness and lead to unrealistic future expectations.
Make an offer that allows room for negotiation and debate.
Suggesting an idea leads to a discussion of parameters. An idea, unlike an offer, does not imply a specific course of action.
An idea suggests directions, alternative paths, and possibilities. An idea is less concrete than an offer.
Proactive negotiators float an idea when they're trying to determine the broadest frame of negotiation.
Suggesting an idea helps a negotiator see whether the other party's broad issues are consistent with their own.
However broad discussion may inhibit specific conversations and offers.
Consider proposing an idea rather than a concrete offer if you're not quite sure how the negotiations will conclude.
Don't suggest an idea that distracts from your primary needs and wants.
An idea should get the conversation started so you can learn about the other party's needs, wants, and alternatives.
Making an inquiry redirects the opening round to the other party.
It neither presents a specific offer nor hints at possible ideas.
Sometimes the proactive negotiator can take control of the process by giving the opening round to the other party.
By asking a question, the proactive negotiator controls the process by choosing not to reveal their exact wishes.
This strategy may create an endless "after-you" loop.
Ask questions that can be answered.
Inquiries should be crafted to learn about the other party's needs, wants, and alternatives.
You might accidentally give control to the other party, possibly losing the advantage of making the opening move.

decks.name: How many issues do you put on the table?

cards.title: When preparing for a negotiation, proactive negotiators think about how many issues they want to introduce.
They may choose to confine the negotiation to a single issue or may introduce multiple issues.
Each approach has its advantages and disadvantages.
Choosing whether to deal with multiple issue or single issues may seem simple, but it's not always clear.
When you have one big, overwhelming issue, try to put it in the context of multiple issues.
Don't get sidetracked because one party decides pushes for random issues. Keep your needs and wants list in front of you.
Working with a single issue gives the negotiations a narrow focus.
A single-issue negotiation allows for an incremental approach, and the potential to resolve other issues that aren't necessarily on the table.
The single-issue approach eliminates the possibility of trade-offs.
A single-issue negotiation is more likely to result in a clear winner and a clear loser, as there's less likely room to wrangle an agreement that both parties are satisfied with.
A single-issue negotiation is a zero-sum game and requires greater bargaining power
You have to be prepared to lose and lose big if you only focus on a single issue.
A single-issue negotiation means there is less room for creative solutions.
Multiple-issue negotiations are more flexible and fluid.
Dealing with multiple issues gives the negotiations a broad focus.
Working with multiple issues enables a non-incremental approach, potentially resolving several issues at once.
Having multiple issues enhances the possibility of trade-offs.
Dealing with a number of issues offers you flexibility and tactical maneuverability.
If you have multiple issues in front of you, you can engage in trade-offs.
The multiple-issue approach requires you to think about your needs and wants.

decks.name: How to deal with multiple issues

cards.title: Simple agenda: Each party makes a list of issues, and then negotiates in a prescribed order.
Hard issues first: Both parties create a list of issues, specifying one or two that are particularly difficult, and deal with those first.
Soft issues first: Both parties specify one or two issues that will be less difficult to resolve and start with those.
Trade-off: Each party begins by conceding an issue and working from there.
Deciding which strategy to follow is a personal decision, but there can be an advantage in starting with the soft issues first.
By dealing with soft issues first, trust can be established.
If you tackle the harder issues first and fail, you could be in trouble.
You might decide to switch strategies midstream, as you and the other party get to know each other's priorities and parameters.
If the negotiations are complex, keep a written list in front of you and stay focused. In the heat of negotiations, it's easy to lose sight of what you really need to accomplish.
Negotiations occur against an ethical backdrop that has to do with truth-telling. Is omitting information the same as lying?
Proactive negotiators understand the dual dilemmas deeply embedded in every negotiation.
By trusting someone completely, the proactive negotiator gains the opportunity to make a deal, but at the same time, they are aware of their vulnerability and guard against being taken advantage of.
The proactive negotiator closely monitors the trust equation.
The proactive negotiator asks, "How much can I trust the other person? How much of what he says is true?"
To keep negotiations moving forward, you want to avoid a circular situation where dishonesty leads to mistrust and mistrust leads to dishonesty.
You also want to avoid being totally candid when the other party isn't being candid. Candor and trust must be reciprocated.
If the other party is not candid, you leave yourself vulnerable. The challenge is to walk the middle line.
Proactive negotiators understand that negotiations have ethical and moral constraints. There are some are situations when disclosure is mandatory and others when bluffing is acceptable.
Bluffing occurs when one party does not share complete information.
A proactive negotiator bluffs when they make their goals intentionally ambiguous.
A proactive negotiator bluffs when they lead their opponent to believe they want more than they really need.
The realm of bluff involves managing impressions about intentions and interpretations.
When dealing with facts and data which can be confirmed, disclosure is appropriate. Never bluff about something that's easy to verify.
You can't lie about not being able to pay someone $25 dollars an hour, but you can discuss how hard it would be to do so.
There are three classic bluffs:
The resource bluff: One party tries to convince the other party that its resources exceed what can be objectively verified.
The dependence bluff: The first party tries to convince the second party that they are highly dependent on the resources controlled by the first party.
The sanction bluff: The first party attempts to convince the second party that they will apply sanctions against the second party when, in fact, they are not able or willing to do so.
Use caution when employing any type of bluff.
Bluffing is all about "fishing" for information. It is a tactic to feel out the other party's weaknesses and strengths.
A proactive negotiator's bluffing potential is determined not only by their position, but also by the information they have about the other party's position.
Proactive negotiators with less information might chose to bluff in order to gain a slight advantage.
If neither party has much information about the other, there is a high likelihood of bluffing on both sides, as they fish for information about each other.
If both parties have a lot of information about each other, the likelihood of bluffing is low. If it does occur, it will be used to pinpoint areas of greatest vulnerability.
Always be prepared to have your bluff called. You don't want to find yourself out of a job because you declared you would quit if you didn't get such-and-such.
Bluff only if you are prepared to lose.
Emotions influence negotiation patterns and outcomes.
Some negotiators might slip up due to anger. Others might feel compassion or are sorry for the other party, and consequently, rein in their demands.
There is a difference between showing genuine emotion and tactically expressing emotion.
A proactive negotiator who can produce a controlled and calculated outburst can often use it to win support for their position.
Proactive negotiators self-regulate and self-monitor their emotions and know when to overplay or underplay specific emotions.
Beware of emotion. It can get the better of you and you may end up tipping your hand.
Balance your emotions as best as you possibly can.
Proactive negotiators can choose to frame the negotiations positively or negatively.
Positive emotions send a message of inclusion.
Positive emotions help form a social bond between negotiating parties.
By using positive emotions, proactive negotiators show the other party that they are in a position to have an impact on them.
Proactive negotiators use positive emotions to signal their willingness to be flexible.
Be positive if you think others will react well to this style.
By starting positive, you are likely to develop a trusting relationship. Be careful not to leave yourself vulnerable.
Be positive if you want to learn more about the needs and wants of the other party.
When a negotiator uses negative emotions, they risk pushing the other party away.
Using negative emotions highlights the differences between the parties.
The negotiator who uses negative emotions conveys that they have little regard for the position or ideas of the other party.
By drawing a line in the sand, you may get more concessions from the other party.
Adopt a negative approach to present a strong, coordinated agenda.

decks.name: The value & risks of using empathy

cards.title: When using emotion, the proactive negotiator expresses empathy without being condescending and shows anger without being personally hostile.
Empathy is more than just knowing the other party's needs and wants; empathy means understanding how the other party arrived at their needs and wants and why they're valuable.
Empathy can improve negotiations by enhancing a sense of partnership and creating a greater degree of trust and understanding.
Empathy is a long process that has the potential to sidetrack negotiations. A negotiator with a great deal of empathy might concede more than they intended or be blind to potential threats.
Empathy may have short-run risks, but it's likely to preserve or enhance relationships over the long haul.
Your challenge is to be empathetic without appearing weak.
Be empathetic, but don't let it blind you.
Emotions should be tactical cues, not spontaneous eruptions.
Proactive negotiators can heat things up (escalate) or cool things down (de-escalate) in negotiations, depending on their intention.
Escalation must be calculated. With too much escalation--facts can go out the window as one or both parties start presenting purely personal reasons for supporting their side.
To de-escalate, one party can diffuse the situation by pivoting from personal to fact-based issues. Doing so will bring the negotiation back to reality.
Understand that emotions exist on a continuum. You have to ask yourself where on the continuum you want to be.
Be careful when using emotion, as people will remember outbursts, name calling, and other missteps.
Using emotions might result in residual effects that can last long after the negotiation process is concluded.
In the workplace, sometimes it is not obvious who the right person is to negotiate with.
Before deciding to negotiate with someone, a proactive negotiator makes sure the other party knows the issues and knows what's going on.
The proactive negotiator also makes sure the other party has the power to make an agreement.
Most importantly, the proactive negotiator only starts negotiations with someone who has the capacity to deliver on the agreement.
When negotiating, you need to be sure you're dealing with the right person.
You can waste valuable time and weaken your position by opening a negotiation with the wrong person.

decks.name: Consequences of negotiating with the wrong person

cards.title: A proactive negotiator is aware of the adverse consequences of opening negotiations with a person who lacks the power and position to negotiate.
By talking to the wrong person, a negotiator wastes time and effort and goes nowhere.
A negotiator who negotiates with the wrong person might tip their hand and broadcast information they did not want out of the bag.
Engaging the wrong person will make a negotiator appear to be out the loop. By the time they discover the right party to negotiate with, their position may be weakened.
It might slowly dawn on you that you're talking to the wrong person. When you come to the realization that you're spinning your wheels, exit the situation right away!
Make sure you do your homework to ensure that you are talking to someone who can green-light agreements.
Someone's personality will often affect their negotiating style. A proactive negotiator will anticipate the personality of the other party to learn something about their negotiation style.
Extraverts have a tendency to be positive, open, and willing to engage in conversation. Proactive negotiators would do well to match their energy.
Conscientious types are concerned with details, always prepared, and like things done in the right way. Proactive negotiators should present them with facts, data, and information.

People with Machiavellian personalities will do whatever it takes to win. They will likely have hidden agendas, and they will tell you what you want to hear. Proactive negotiators should present them with many options and avoid attacking their position.

People who are open have great imaginations, think abstractly, and are excited by new ideas. Proactive negotiators should feel free to present them with new ideas, but at the same time, they should be focused.
Be aware of how your personality tendencies might affect your negotiation style.
You don't need to know everything about the other party. You just need an idea of how they will react to your needs and wants.
Culture is the result of the psychosocial factors that shape values, a sense of collective identity, and underlying ideologies.
People's approaches to negotiations are affected not only by their personalities and interests, but by the hidden beliefs that they take for granted.
Culture determines not only what is negotiable, but what is nonnegotiable.
Some cultures feel it's crucial to establish a friendship before negotiations can begin, while others desire to preserve pride and status at all costs.
Proactive negotiators understand that they also operate within a corporate culture. Some organizations encourage debate, while others do not.
Don't overly generalize culture. It's a clue, not a key to negotiation
Think about your culture and how it affects your negotiation style.
The external environment that an organization operates in is huge; with globalization an organization's external environment is becoming more complex.

It is crucial for innovation leaders to be externally aware. Innovation leaders are sensitive to the changing realities that might prompt an organization to become more clunky or concentric in nature.
Innovation leaders continuously explore the external environment and assess the internal organization's capacity to drive strategy and avoid falling into the trap of becoming clunky.
The external environment is comprised of five main areas:
1. Clients, consumers, & customers
2. Suppliers (materials, products, and labor)
3. Market competitors
4. Government or regulatory agencies
5. New technologies
Innovation leaders do a number of things to keep aware of external trends.
Innovation leaders continuously research their competitors.
Innovation leaders stay on top of cultural and market trends.
Innovation leaders stay ahead of the curve.
Innovation leaders create partnerships and form networks with a wide array of knowledge providers.
Innovation leaders explore customer needs
Always be vigilant about reading your external environment.
Sometimes there are internal barriers to innovation within organizations (even start-ups).
Innovation can be stymied when the structure of the organization is too complex.
When separate functions don't meet or network on a regular basis, there is limited communication and even less collaboration.
Often innovation is a stated priority for the organization, but it is often not incentivized for managers.
Too much customer focus can lead to endless revisions of old products.
Internal processes can hold up innovation through paperwork, red tape, and bureaucracy. Worse, inertia can set in.
If a team is only focused on sales, they won't be focused on finding new ideas.
Be aware of the barriers of innovation--and expect them.
Consider: "What is the biggest barrier to innovation in your organization?"
Innovation leaders try to shape internal processes in the following ways:
They make sure business units regularly exchange information.
They create diverse teams with varied expertise and problem-solving approaches.
They engage in knowledge forums.
They create internal knowledge centers where ideas, books and articles, and other information is shared.
In organizations, innovation is a group activity.
Groups energize innovation because they can bring multiple perspectives to a problem or challenge.
Different perspectives help surface different questions and novel lines of investigation.
In the best case, group members work together, encourage each other, and create unity.
Groups have natural conversations and discuss ideas openly.
As a collective, a group can take more risks and face fewer individual repercussions.
Innovation leaders are aware that groups can have real limitations.
Groups sometimes have a tendency to get behind the most popular (not necessarily the best) idea or be swayed by the most dominate personality.
If a group or team cuts itself off from the rest of the organization, it can become insular.
Groups can protect their own self-interest or the interest of their unit/team without caring about creating innovation.
While competition can help motivate people and groups, too much competition can create discord.
Groups can replicate organizational hierarchy and when the power structure is reinforced, individual creativity can diminish.
Individuals may be reluctant to share their ideas because they are shy or don't want to look silly.
As an innovation leader, you want to make sure everyone feels included and has a voice.

decks.name: The levels of the innovation hub

cards.title: Innovation leaders know how to organize, manage, and create innovation hubs and balance group dynamics.
There are four levels to the innovation hub:
1. Individual team or hub members.
2. Hot groups: A micro team of individuals committed to shared ideas, beliefs, and work practices (ex.: a group of engineers).
3. Team: The entire personnel of a team, department, or sector (ex.: the engineers plus their research associates, support staff, and interns).
4. Organization: The entire business or corporation.
Think about the hot groups in your organization, department, or team.
Hot groups generally have a flat structure, a strong identity, and a zeal for a particular vision.
Innovation leaders have to inspire each level of the innovation hub.
Innovation leaders work hard to inspire individual creativity and celebrate new ideas and perspectives.
Innovation leaders maintain a hot group's synergy to increase or sustain innovation. They support the hot group and ensure they have the necessary resources.
Innovation leaders coordinate their teams to make sure they are operating at optimal levels.
Innovation leaders make sure all levels of the hub feel included and responsible. They don't just focus on the hot groups.
Innovation leaders make sure their teams, hubs, and individuals aren't given too much pressure by organizational leaders and are allowed to fail and learn from mistakes.
Ideally teams should have 5-9 people, but this isn't a hard-and-fast rule.
There are four main personalities in an innovation hub:
1. Realists: Prefer to work around grounded activity with a specific outcome. They could process things to death
2. Doers: Thrive when they push, support, and maintain innovative ideas. They could fail to adjust under pressure.
3. Drivers: Advance innovation and make sure it's realized. They could go off the cliff.
4. Dreamers: Stretch the envelope and help organizational actors get acclimated to seismic change. However, they could tear the envelope asunder.
What composition of players do you want on your team? Ideally, you'd create a balance.
Psychological fear inhibits innovation. It is the responsibility of innovation leaders to provide psychological safety for their team or hub. Types of fear:
1. Fear of judgment: Hub members might not speak up because they don't want their ideas to be perceived as wild or weak.
2. Fear of usurpation: Hub members might avoid connecting opposing ideas to avoid being trumped by a better idea.
3. Fear of power-loss (status): If hub members feel their proposals are risky, they may worry about losing status.
4. Fear of isolation (ostracization): Hub members don't want to be left in the cold because they supported an idea that might be rejected by the group.
5. Fear of envelopment: Hub members may fear being drowned out and overwhelmed.
Innovation leaders challenge and push new ideas, but never push or demand a specific course of action.
Innovation leaders ask open-ended questions to produce forward movement.
To inspire innovation, leaders give constructive feedback to build on ideas, not take them down.
Innovation leaders intervene tactically when projects or creative sessions go off track.
Innovation leaders evaluate, but not judge, ideas.
Innovation leaders maintain curiosity and are excited about new ideas.
Innovation leaders reinforce optimism when energy wanes and help produce excitement and pride in a project.
There is no creativity without psychological safety.
Innovation leaders engage to create safety in the following ways:
1. They dialogue with their team members authentically; they are attentive and understanding.
2. Innovation leaders enhance their team by providing resources and eliminating hierarchies.
3. Innovation leaders are emphatic and consider the problems and difficulties team members may have.
5. Lastly, innovation leaders avoid the ego trap and don't look at every issue as if it revolves around them.
Value creativity, but don't process things to death.
Don't fall into the trap of perpetual discussion.
A loose canvas defines a system that is open and doesn't hinge on other components and constraints.
Innovation leaders want to work with a loose canvas when there are few constraints, resources are flowing, and the direction is unclear.
A loose canvas platform creates many ideas and can be exciting and far reaching.
With a loose canvas, leaders risk losing time and keeping focus.
Create a loose canvas environment when you have a broad challenge without an exacting deadline.
A tight canvas defines a system that works within a narrow scope and has a clear direction.
Innovation leaders prefer a tight canvas when time constraints are real, resources are tight, and the direction is clear.
A tight canvas platform leads to efficient, focused, driven conversations.
With a tight canvas, leaders risk constricting creative thought and stifling divergent ideas.
A tight canvas is necessary when time is short and resources are scarce.
Innovation leaders try to find a balance between these two platforms.
Divergent thinking is about getting a diverse group of people together to throw around as many ideas as possible.
Innovation leaders never dismiss an idea as too crazy or too extreme. All ideas and viewpoints are entertained during the divergence process.
Innovation leaders inspire opposing, varied, and exciting ideas. Only later in the process do they begin to evaluate the ideas.
Remember: "The way to get good ideas is to get lots of ideas and throw the bad ones away." Linus Pauling
Innovation leaders foster divergence in the following ways:
1. Innovation leaders raise awareness of biases so a group can work around them or avoid them.
2. It's always easy to work with the same people, but innovation leaders push their teams to get beyond their comfort zone. Familiarity can create complacency.
3. Innovation leaders embrace outliers and embrace people with fresh perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences.
4. Innovation leaders step beyond rules and corporate traditions and challenge them.
5. People will experiment with new ideas if they know that failure is seen as another step in the path--not as an excuse to evaluate and sanction. Innovation leaders reward failure.
6. Divergent thinking is often stultified by the short-term mentality of immediate needs. Innovation leaders anticipate future problems.
7. Innovation leaders are driven by problems, not by available solutions.

8. Nothing is more destructive to divergent thinking than the drive to reduce cognitive dissonance and to seek rationalization and accommodation to resolve contradictions. Innovation leaders embrace contradiction.
9. Chaos is a source of spontaneity. Innovation leaders believe improvisation and spontaneity is the essence of divergence.
10. Innovation leaders aren't afraid of silence and reflection.
Innovation leaders can ask a variety of questions to stimulate divergence, including:
What is possible? How do you see this/ the situation/problem? What is not yet clear?
What do you want to explore? What other angles can you think of?
If you had no obstacles, what would you do? What will doing this way get you?
Can you think of others?
The next step of the innovation process revolves around convergence; that is, the process of combining the best ideas developed during the divergence process.
Innovation leaders help their team mix ideas together and come up with unique idea combinations.
Innovation leaders need to be aware of the three major convergence barriers:
1. Information overload: When there are too many ideas or too much information it can be harder for teams to connect divergent ideas.
2. Early dismissal: Innovation leaders often pass on ideas far too early in the process, when, in fact, they might prove be fruitful.
3. Inadequate filters: Without knowing the appropriate vision, convergence can be aimless.
To converge innovation leaders do the following things:
1. Look for holes: Exploit gaps. Breaks in knowledge can help. Astronomers discovered outer planets not by sight, but by shadows.
2. Group by category: Find like categories and connect.
3. Look for outliers: Bring in ideas from the periphery.
4. Unify themes: Cluster ideas that share a theme.
5. Make obvious connections: Explore clear links.
6. Juxtapose extremes: Draw links between opposing ideas.
7. Look for patterns: Find patterns from which you can draw connections.
After innovation leaders diverge and converge, they are left (in the best case) with a few ideas worth pursuing.
It's an innovation leader's job to select the best idea, but with careful consideration.
Innovation leaders need to determine which of the competing ideas are game changers or not worth the effort.

decks.name: Nine criteria for evaluating the best concept

cards.title: Instead of making a random selection, innovation leaders evaluate competing ideas using the following criteria:
1. Occam's Razor: Select an idea that makes the fewest assumptions.
2. Accessibility: Select an idea that is most accessible and available.
3. Practicality: Select the idea that is most practical and doable.
4. Scalability: Choose the idea that can be expanded and developed.
5. Reliability: Pick the idea that can hold up over time.
6. Emotional appeal: Does the idea connect with a certain audience?
7. Utility: Select the idea that fulfills a need.
8. Dissemination of potential: Select the idea that will succeed in the organizational context.
9. Revenue opportunity: Can the idea turn a profit?
The manager who relies on directive leadership takes a full-steam-ahead and do-it-by-the-numbers approach to momentum.
Directive leaders stick with the program, follow instructions, and implement.
Directive leaders tell their employees what they want, how to do it, and when they want it done.
The directive leader views the average person as not self-motivated, comfortable with inertia, and willing to avoid any possibility of chaos or uncertainty at any cost.

Embedded here is the notion that to sustain momentum, people cannot simply be motivated, but that they must be driven, coordinated, directed, supervised, and pointed toward the organizational objectives.
The more a leader can predict events and make the activities routine, the greater their capacity to implement and keep moving with a directive leadership style.
Directive managers believe that they can maximize momentum by minimizing uncertainty and ensure implementation by maximizing control.
Directive leaders want their group to have explicit, specific, clearly stated goals that everyone in the group works toward.
A facilitative leader puts the emphasis on an individual's ability to reflect, innovate, and problem solve.

A manager who places emphasis on facilitative skills to sustain momentum assumes that most individuals are self-motivated and appreciate challenge. Facilitative leaders are willing to take risks and value problem solvers.
Facilitative leaders are unafraid of uncertainty and chaos. They feel that given the proper conditions, people learn, adapt, use their imagination, and live up to their intellectual potential.
Unlike directive leaders, who assume that only small groups have power, facilitative leaders distribute power more broadly.
For a facilitative leader, organizations are more like networks than hierarchies; in these “learning organizations,” workers are team members and problem solvers.
When you act as a facilitative leader, you're aware that your role is to enhance people's capacity to make creative and appropriate decisions when faced with uncertainty.
You can see how the issues associated with a facilitative approach are very different from those associated with a directive approach.
A proactive leader should balance both leadership styles without relying on one too heavily.
Directive leadership may achieve results, but it can create employee burnout and drain momentum.
While a facilitative approach accommodates fast-moving, fast-changing situations, it can ignore the basic realities of implementation: time and focus.
A proactive leader should adopt a directive approach when there is a tight deadline or a specific target and a facilitative approach when opportunities are broader and challenges less defined.
Managing for momentum is a study in contradictions. It is a question of knowing how to balance these two distinct styles.

Directive leadership sustains momentum through control. This leadership style is based on telling people what needs to be done, allocating resources, making expectations clear, defining goals, and establishing the parameters of success and failure.
Facilitative leadership sustains momentum by creating a sense of community and a sense of autonomy.
Sometimes projects just fall apart and momentum dies out because no one is quite sure who is in charge.
If leaders don't focus on who's in charge and who's accountable, nothing will get done.

To minimize blatant turf battles and to avoid your initiative getting trapped by no one knowing who is responsible and who is in charge, leaders need to make decisions about who reports to whom and what activities should occur in what departments.
Structure in an organization provides a façade of order.
Leaders who think it's important to be directive emphasize hierarchies.
Leaders who think it's important to be facilitative emphasize teams.
The challenge for your managerial competence is not to select one structure over another, but to know under what conditions which structure is the most appropriate.
If you want to sustain momentum by keeping control and maintaining predictability, your emphasis should be directive and focused on a vertical hierarchical structure.
If you want to sustain momentum by driving innovation and creativity, your emphasis should be facilitative and focused on a horizontal team structure.
The strength of a hierarchical structure is that it maximizes control.
That might mean limiting the number of people who have decision-making responsibility or reducing the number of work units.
Hierarchical structure works well when you need to simply execute.
Leaders use hierarchy to sustain momentum by placing an emphasis on predictability, consistency, and accountability.
A directive leader one who favorsclear hierarchies believes that without authority, nothing will get done.
If you rely too much on vertical hierarchical structures, you may be trapped in bureaucratic inertia.
A more facilitative leadership style is not organized around strict hierarchy, but around groups or teams.
Whereas the directive leader emphasizes hierarchy to sustain momentum, the facilitative leader sees the importance of clustering, dialogue, and collaboration as keys to getting things done.
A facilitative leader is not convinced that the chain of command is the answer.
Instead, they value sharing ideas, working collaboratively, and developing their own sense of internal momentum.
The facilitative leader believes the key to sustainingmomentum is the power of the people, not the power of the hierarchy.
If you want to sustain momentum by driving innovation and creativity, your emphasis should be facilitative and focused on a horizontal team structure.
If you rely too much on horizontal team structure you may be caught in the quagmire of turf battles.
Your managerial competence will be tested by your capacity to balance this range of options.
Enhancing momentum requires resources. Without money, people, space, supplies, leaders can't build energy.
Proactive leaders must be able to provide adequate resources to build and sustain momentum.
Some leaders provide ample resources, reasoning that if the staff has enough, then they will have what they need to get things done.
Some managers instinctively allocate more resources to a project, believing that more people, more equipment, and more support will enhance the project's momentum.
But there might be a point of diminishing returns. Resources can't fix every problem.
If people in your organization have more than sufficient access to resources, they may deploy those resources in ways that are not productive for your initiative.

You've seen this time and again in organizations. Money is spent on seemingly unnecessary activities and materials. Ask about these expenditures and suddenly no one knows who is using the resources or how they were procured in the first place.
However, more resources means more complexity, which require a greater bureaucracy.
At the other extreme, leaders can be directive and institute a “starvation strategy."
By severely limiting resources, people can become very creative about getting things done.

In fact, some managers reason that if workers are deliberately resource-constrained, they could come up with better and more cost-effective solutions than they would have if they had unlimited resources.
This is an attractive philosophy, but it is also a very risky proposition. What if creative solutions can't be found?
You can starve an initiative in the name of cost consciousness or conservation.
Don't tighten the screws to the point that the project suffocates.
Sweeping visions AND resource deprivation will kill momentum and drive people away.
Leaders need to make sure that their team's access to organizational resources does not fall below a certain threshold.
Proactive leaders monitor their team and make sure the team doesn't shift from being “hungry” to “discouraged."
Too many managers are insensitive to this threshold and don't provide “slack” for exploring and drawing on resources to pursue the goals of the initiative.
There is no science to this. It is much more of an intuitive feel and sensitivity to your group's level of motivation and creativity.
In giving people resources, you can't afford to facilitate every whim or directively restrict every paperclip. It can't be feast or famine.
You need to find that point where limitations placed on resources do not jeopardize momentum, but enhance and inspire novel solutions.
Organizational behaviorists call this the job structure issue.
Leaders who structure the job correctly will be able to sustain momentum.
Failure to structure the job correctly, regardless of resources, will prevent leaders from pushing projects forward.
In trying to sustain this aspect of structural momentum, you have to balance your facilitative tendency to give people autonomy and your directive leaning to be prescriptive.
Advocates of sustaining momentum through routinization of work processes seek a high degree of control and direction over the work that gets done in their group.
Routinized work processes are, perhaps, the most common way of sustaining momentum in organizations, particularly in manufacturing and production-oriented organizations.
Routinization of work processes attempts to maximize clarity about how work should be performed in the organization.
As such, employees working in organizations with a simplified approach tend to be more focused on carrying out well-defined tasks.
There is a tendency for leaders to prefer routinized work processes. Indeed, it would be nice if all work could be codified and described in a fairly concise user's manual.
But if a team needs to problem solve to any degree--routinization falls short.

If you try to sustain momentum by assigning tasks and routinizing activities in areas where you should be giving autonomy and creating problem solvers, you'll find that the work is not getting done with the quality or at the pace you'd like.
Still, routinizing work processes can help improve profitability and growth if there is a lot of task-oriented work.
When trying to sustain momentum, routinized work processes will generally not do well when the group is going through periods of change or when changes will require that things are done differently.
Leaders provide autonomy to their teams when they want to encourage a problem-solving orientation over a task orientation.
The underlying premise is that with autonomy, team members can make appropriate decisions and feel a continued sense of involvement.
Giving people discretion and autonomy works best when sustaining momentum under conditions of volatility and ambiguity.
But when uncertainty has permeated a organization, loose work processes can be a much more effective approach to getting things done than routinized processes.
When trying to maintain momentum when there is a high degree of certainty and predictability, you should not overdo discretion and autonomy.
The challenge leaders face is finding the right balance between relying on routinization and giving people discretion and autonomy.
In trying to sustain this aspect of structural momentum, you have to balance your facilitative tendency to give people autonomy and your directive leaning to be prescriptive.
In trying to sustain momentum, you have to keep in mind one of the cardinal rules of keeping people on your side: People want autonomy, but they also need parameters and limits.
Routinize through job descriptions and detailed specifications but provide autonomy by making the job as flexible as possible.
An important part of every leader's job is to provide teams with clarity around the criteria they will use to evaluate process and performance and standards that they will hold members to.
In sustaining momentum, one of the most essential things is to be able to make evaluations, but one of the most difficult things is to know what to evaluate.
Nothing will slow down an initiative more than getting everybody up in arms because they don't know what is being evaluated, or worse, they think you're evaluating the wrong thing.
There are two types of information you can gather: bottom-line measures such as productivity and quality or process information.
While monitoring and evaluating are critical to sustaining momentum, if not done correctly, you'll drive people away and not be able to keep them on your side.
Output measures are the bottom-line indicators of success or failure. These measures include productivity, quality, and innovation.
Evaluating output helps leaders keep focused on results.
Output tends to be tangible and generally measurable. So, it holds appeal to both those who are evaluating results and those who are trying to produce results.
But output measures are tricky and are subjective. Productivity and quality can be affected by many factors, even those outside of the immediate control of the organization.
Processes are about how things get done how people carry out their work. Sometimes the most obvious thing to evaluate is how well individuals carry out their activities.
Leaders look at underlying processes that may impact bottom-line measures. They ask: "How well do they implement an initiative? How well do they do the job?"
And when you evaluate process, there remains tremendous subjectivity and ambiguity.
Leaders have to be clear about the subjective bottom line.
There are many measures of output and processes. Any measure of progress is, at best, a moving target.
As a managerially competent leader, you must be aware that subjective or not, stable or not, you have an obligation to be clear how projects and people will be evaluated.
If you fail to do this, you will not be able to keep people on your side and sustain momentum
After measuring the performance of a team, a leader will want to make adjustments, but they need to be careful not overreact or underreact.
Adjustments are an inevitable part of any initiative. Very few efforts go exactly as planned.
It is at these moments that proactive leaders need to take action…but they have to be careful not to go too far. It is a delicate balance, fraught with challenges and risks.
Making adjustments is dependent not simply on the information you gather, but also on the nuances and subtleties you project in giving feedback to others regarding the need for adjustments.
Comments you view as constructive, others may perceive as hostile. What you may view as an essential truth, others may see as an obfuscation of reality.
Overreacting is a strategy that leaders choose to assure that they won't be perceived as "falling asleep at the wheel."
They will denounce critics with comments like, "Well, at least I did something!"
They will take every piece of information and take action based on that information.
These leaders seem to be unable to prioritize or filter the fundamentally important information they receive from the anecdotal, anomalous information that is pervasive in organizations.
Overreactive leaders fail to realize is that with every shift, they erode the momentum they've previously built.
Remember: People who work on projects led by overactive leaders are likely to burnout or become frustrated by the frenetic action and stunted progress of the initiative.
People don't remain engaged with an initiative unless they are continually learning, being challenged, and/or have a sense that they are developing as professionals.
Leaders make adjustments using empathy and feedback.
When making adjustments it is critical that you are empathetic. This means viewing the adjustment from the perspective of others and understanding their interests, orientation, fears, and anxieties.

Being empathetic is not a glib "I-feel-your-pain" attitude, but sitting down and delving into the feelings and perspectives of others, the specifics of the situation, and the objectives of your agenda.
For most people, the right amount of empathy is simply listening.
If you want to sustain momentum, you have to put feedback in the context of a mentoring relationship.
When you give feedback as a mentor, rather than as a supervisor, you move a long way toward using feedback as developmental tool rather than a performance review stick.
A problem-solving culture is one where the questions “What went wrong?” and “What went right?” are part and parcel of everyday behavior in the organization.
A problem-solving culture is one where it is customary to openly discuss work-related errors.
It is a culture where people feel free to surface problems.
It is a culture where suggestions and comments are valued.
Don't let problem solving become the problem.
In creating a culture that encourages questions, leaders have a choice between a reflexive or reflective problem-solving culture.
Reflexive leaders focus on improving the specifics doing what they've done before, just doing it little bit better, a little more frequently, a little faster, or a little more cost-effectively.
A manager trying to sustain momentum in a reflexive problem-solving culture integrates new ideas in a fairly rudimentary fashion.
And if the ideas don't fit appropriately, he or she will disregard the ideas and continue on his or her way.
A reflexive problem-solving culture allows leaders to stay on track, sustain momentum, and deal with minor variations.
With a reflexive problem-solving culture, a leader can adapt quickly to a new situation, but will not necessarily be known as an innovator.
Directive leaders tend to be comfortable with a more reflexive problem-solving culture.
You are a reflexive leader if you prefer to tinker with processes and reengineer habits without completely overhauling a system.
A leader working in a reflective problem-solving culture asks how new ideas fit into ongoing agendas and initiatives.
A manager who is a reflective problem solver will not only evaluate new ideas on the basis of whether they are appropriate for the agenda, but will evaluate the agenda in terms of the new ideas.
A reflective problem-solving culture allows leaders to make major adjustments, deal with crisis, and constantly change the processes.
Facilitative leaders emphasize establishing a reflective problem-solving culture, where there is reevaluation and reflection on what should be learned and integrated each step of the way.
They are inclined toward overhauling and putting the unit on a new trajectory.
Individuals will be more committed to your initiative, will help sustain momentum, and stay on your side in a situation where they are learning and improving.
However, leaders don't want to create a situation where there is nonstop learning and problem solving with people continuously sharing interesting articles--at the expense of getting the work done.

Problem-solving cultures are sometimes reduced to perpetual reflection, where everyone is engaging in self-reflection, having their say, and meeting with constant discussion, and slowing things down to a snail's pace.
There has to be a time when you have to stop learning and problem solving and move ahead.
Sometimes you have to stop being reflective and start being reflexive.  You have to stop thinking and start acting.
To sustain momentum, you must be able to balance both reflexive and reflective learning.
A strong sense of community will enhance momentum.
People who feel this sense of community are likely to stay on your side and go the distance while waving the group's flag.
They will defend the group's actions and show explicit pride in its accomplishments.
They will go that extra mile for the group beyond their explicit job description.
The collective has become greater than any individual and a source of sustenance.
When you have a strong collective, you have immense energy to push your initiative ahead.
But sometimes the collective is simply a burden. Leaders can't always include everyone. Doing so slows down momentum and opens the door to unnecessary criticism, too many discussions, and inertia.
Sometimes the collective with its implied sense of unity and consensus can be a burden.
Another risk in using a sense of collective in sustaining momentum is “groupthink."
Because the collective values conformity, unity, and loyalty, the group will do everything to maintain the sense of collective, which can lead to regrettable decisions.
Don't support the collective for the sake of consensus.
Managerially competent leaders sustain momentum by fostering the individual identities of their community members.
They understand that the individuals on their team need to maintain their individuality, a strong sense of self, and a meaningful, personal identity.
The most successful leaders seek a balance, which creates a strong and powerful sense of affiliation, and allows and encourages members to create and maintain their own individuality and identity.
When establishing cultural momentum your best bet is to recognize the individual within the group.
In sustaining momentum, a managerially competent leader pumps up the collective but never forgets the individual.
People need the sense of recognition. Without it, they may feel that they are taken for granted.
Leaders don't always have to slap their peers on the back. But they should engage in those little gestures, ceremonies, and rites that reinforce individual accomplishments.
Make sure that the rewards, ceremonies, and celebrations are not empty of meaning.
Celebrations make people feel good about where they are and what they are doing.
If a leader celebrates too much, with too many awards, meaning can be lost.
If a leader does not take time to celebrate small wins, they deprive their people of an important source of energy.
Find the right balance and you can sustain energy, engagement, and momentum over the long term.
In sustaining political momentum a leader has to ensure that the coalition mindset doesn't drift away.
In the simplest sense, a coalition is a collection of individuals or groups with common interests who are committed to the achievement of a common goal.
A coalition is a group mobilized for joint action, with shared intentions and a shared understanding of what needs to be done.  The key is the notion of mobilization.
A coalition is formed not by accident or circumstance, but by the focused will of a managerially competent leader to mobilize others for joint action.
A coalition mindset is an energizing force.
As you move forward, your challenge is to sustain this feeling of mobilization, and the sense that collectively something of value can be achieved.
Political momentum can only be sustained with a coalition mindset.
You and your team need to feel that everyone is moving together toward a specific end which everyone is vested in.

decks.name: Four ways to preserve the coalition mindset

cards.title: To keep the coalition mindset going, leaders can do the following four things:
1. Reinvigorate the vision: Managerially competent leaders know how to return to the vision periodically to remind people of the long-term objective.
2. Reinforce the benefits: It is important to reinvigorate vision, but it is equally important to remind everyone of the bottom-line payoff.
3. Sustain optimism: Leaders need to give people a sense that while there may be obstacles and bumps on the road, there will also be success.
4. Maintain credibility: To sustain a coalition mindset, leaders need others to perceive that they have the credibility to push the initiative forward.
The reinvigoration reminder reengages your people emotionally and reestablishes their sense of purpose and sense of vision.
Remember: People will decide whether to stay with your initiative on the basis of the rewards they will be able to reap.
When creating optimism you don't want to be naïve.  If there are obstacles or hurdles in the way of your project, you want to acknowledge that they exist and they can be overcome.
Credibility is a quickly spent commodity. To assure that you sustain the coalition mindset, your credibility needs to be replenished from time to time.
No matter what a leader does, it is inevitable that they will encounter dissent. Not everyone will agree with everything a leader does. Leaders will be challenged.
Dissent and objections to ideas, while uncomfortable, is not dysfunctional.  Dissent can check groupthink in a positive way.
Leaders need to periodically revisit who is on their side, who they want on their side, and who they're willing to let go.
Managers sometimes assume that the best thing they can do to push an initiative is to get as many people on their side as possible and keep them there.
Having everyone in your group creates the potential of enabling the internal Trojan Horse.
Not every Trojan Horse is brought in from outside of the walls of the project. Sometimes, a Trojan Horse can be cobbled together by group members within the confines of your initiative.
You may be able to predict the existence of an outside Trojan Horse and take steps against lasting damage, but the internal Trojan Horse presents its own special opportunity for sabotage.
You need to be vigilant and diligent in sensing changing interests and intents of group members and have the courage to deal with opposition in a forthright and timely manner.
When an initiative begins there is usually a strong sense of a collective with a team or group.
However, as things move along, the solidified group may splinter. Team members may feel their leader is moving too slow or too fast.

Team members become disenfranchised for a number of reasons. Maybe they feel the agenda is no longer relevant. Some may think they don't have the necessary resources while others might maintain the culture is too oppressive.
Leaders have to maintain a degree of cohesion and not let things spin out of control.
Managerially competent leaders have the capacity to differentiate support, dissent, opposition, and resistance among group members.
You need to understand that not everyone who voices some discontent is out to destroy, sabotage, and scuttle your initiative.
Your reaction to internal criticism will vary from being mildly defensive to feeling betrayed.
Avoid the tendency to jump down people's throats at the earliest available opportunity.  This is one sure way of destroying political momentum.
Supporters are those individuals who continue to agree with your agenda and how it is being executed.
While they may raise questions about specifics, the general framework you are pursuing is more than acceptable to them.
They feel the initiative is on the right track, and will have positive results.
Keep supporters in your ranks, but don't put all your focus on them.
Dissenters are those individuals who support an initiative, but may question how it's being executed.
Dissenters still share a common framework, but they want to make some adjustments as you're moving along.
Dissenters want to help, but have their own ideas about how to pull it off.
Opponents, unlike dissenters, are likely to express stronger opposition about what a leader is doing and how they are doing it.
While dissenters may make off-hand remarks and suggestions, opponents are more likely to challenge directly and publicly in an adamant and continuous fashion.
Their language is more confrontational and reflects a stronger sense of urgency.
Once you are seen as having a paranoid overreaction, you will damage your credibility and the credibility of your initiative.
Resistors are those individuals who not only want to challenge a leader, but actively sabotage where a leader is going and how they are getting there.
Resistors will verge on obstruction not only confronting superiors, but blocking them at every turn.
Any reaction you make is public. Once the genie is out of the bottle, there is no way of getting it back in.
A misstep that some inexperienced leaders make is to immediately squelch internal criticism. They view criticism as divisive and as a threat to their ability to lead the effort.
In dealing with internal challenges the choice is between hard or soft tactics. Leaders need to choose between tactics of coercion and tactics of persuasion.
Hard tactics rely on the use of threats and confrontation.  Hard tactics are embedded in a leader's authority to call the shots and are often used as an ultimatum.
The goal of confrontational tactics is to call people to task and the blatant consequences may be to drive them out.
Soft tactics rely on promises and cooptation. Soft tactics are embedded in a leader's personal capacity to influence people.
A managerially competent leader knows when to use which tactic for which situation.
When dealing with dissenters, you many want to use soft tactics. You already know they are inclined to go with your agenda they just would prefer some modification.
With opponents you want to begin with soft tactics.  You want to give them a sense that they are being listened to, but you have to balance your facilitative inclination.
You want to make it clear to them that non-decisions are not acceptable and that you'll be willing to make the hard decisions when the time comes.
In dealing with resistors, you need to understand that you don't need everyone on your side to sustain momentum.
In light of the damage that resistors can wreck on your initiative, you need to make a hard leadership decision you have to decide if you're willing to let them go.
Counter-coalitions will emerge--they are part of organizational life.
Leaders need to understand the difference between counter-coalitions and other groups, such as interest groups and splinter groups.
For the most part, interest groups are passive and don't actively seek to change the direction or mobilize against a specific organizational change effort.
They may try to sway a leader, but they will be relatively passive about it.  Most significantly, interest groups don't act collectively they don't have a sense of a collective interest.
Try to maximize interest group support when possible.
A splinter group acts more strongly than an interest group.
A splinter group understands two things: they aren't happy with what a leader is doing and they want to make modest efforts to change the direction of where the organization is headed.
Unlike interest groups, splinter groups realize the potential for collective action.
Try to isolate splinter groups and don't spend too much time with them.
Both interest groups and splinter groups are easier to deal with than a full-fledged counter-coalition.
A counter-coalition is a group of politically active individuals who disagree with a leader's agenda and will publicly challenge it.
They are aware of their common interests as a group.  They are collectively aware that they are in direct opposition of where you want to go.
A leaders's challenge is to make sure that splinter groups don't become counter-coalitions and t and that they recognize that counter-coalitions can pose a threat to momentum.
Too many group leaders ignore the existence of counter-coalitions, only to find that their initiative was derailed by a group of people who felt threatened by the initiative or change effort.
By not recognizing the existence of counter-coalitions, you run the risk of losing the commitment and support from your core constituents.
Group members are rarely comfortable if you are seen as the ostrich with its head in the sand while resistance is bubbling.
By not recognizing counter-coalitions, you can lull a group into complacency.
A leader has to make sure that splinter groups don't become counter-coalitions and recognize the challenge that counter-coalitions can pose to momentum.
Leaders need to be aware when these splinter groups or counter-coalitions develop and understand the underlying agendas that each group has.
Leaders who keep people on their side recognize and pay attention to resistance, counter-coalitions, and splinter groups.
Overreacting to counter-coalitions can be as damaging as ignoring their very existence.
Leaders find the balance where they remain aware of the existence of counter-coalitions and respond to their position in an appropriate and measured way.

By paying too much attention to sources of opposition, you may inadvertently give those groups legitimacy that they would not have had you simply recognized their existence, but did little else to respond to their arguments.

Overly emphatic responses to a counter-coalition can cause people in your group begin to take cues from you and spend more of their time responding to the counter-coalition than they do pursuing the group's agenda.
You can't be overly responsive to criticism and opposition, nor can you ignore the very existence of counter-coalitions.
To maintain traction, leaders can do the following six things.
1. Create short-term wins.
2. Provide evidence that the sacrifices are worth it.
3. Reward innovation change agents.
4. Help fine-tune vision and strategies.
5. Undermine cynics and self-serving resistors.
6. Keep bosses on board.
